b"b' Per ticket #2169
column11: I developed logic in the form helper to use the key as part of the validation.  The logic requires that the model structure be passed to the _isRequiredField function.  When the function loops through validateProperties
column12: the new logic looks for the key.  If it is set
column13: and the model structure is passed
column14: then it checks to see if the current request has an id.  It uses the key and the request model id to determine if the rule is valid or not. In my testing
column15: this worked.  I cannot think of a circumstance where the action would be update and there would be no primary key in the request data.  Conversely
column16: if there is no primary key in the request data
column17: then the action would always be create
column18: correct?  So
column19: I think that this should cover all situations.'"

b"b' making messages() and errors() reset themselves by default'"
b"b' Folder should have a reset method to prevent multiple commands interfering with each other.right now
column11: a command that throws errors or messages would also affect following commands on the same object.Allowing the developer to call Folder::delete() between multiple commands removes this issue. EDIT: now making messages() and errors() reset themselves by default'"

column10: b'b" The method name doesn\'t clearly convey that it only clears object state
column11: doesn\'t actually perform any operation on the folder itself."'

column10: b'b" How about just adding a parameter to Folder::messages() and Folder::errors() to clear the arrays instead of returning. It would then require 2 function calls to clear the messages and errors but I don\'t think it would be too much extra trouble."'
b"b' I simply used the same naming conventions as for HttpSocket::reset()
column11: CakeEmail::reset() etc.But two calls would probably work
column12: too.We could also name it resetState() to make it clearer. I find a single method more convenient and cleaner.'"

column10: b"b' Why not just make a new instance?'"
b"b' making a new instance for just another operation on the exact same folder seems to be more overhead than just having a simple reset to be called.'"

b"b' Why not have each method reset the messages automatically?  Seems a bit silly to append new messages onto the old ones.  This avoids a new method as well.  I could see it in the realm of bug land that messages are not reset.'"
b"b' so a param (default true)?thats ok with me'"
b"b' @markstory That would have issues with nested calls
column11: eg. Folder::create() calls itself so  would be lost to the user if they are reset for each run of the function. Edit: I meant Folder::create() not Folder::read()'"

column10: b"b' @ADmad I think what mark means
column11: is that not create but messages() and errors() should reset themselves after they have been called. they are not called anywhere inside
column12: only by the developer from the outside.'"

column10: b"b' @ADmad  Ah bugger
column11: I forgot about that. Is there any particular reason we need messages & errors?  Or is it the kind of feature we could just remove in the future?  From what I can see the messages are generally just a log of what happened.  And errors could probably be replaced with exceptions
column12: as they are generally used when operations fail. For now I guess having the ability to reset  on read is simpler than adding more methods.'"

column10: b"b' @markstory Yes the messages are just a log and replacing the errors with exception is an option. There is a caveat though. There are quite a few situations when a single function call performs operation on multiple folders where the operation can succeed on some and fail on others. Currently it just adds an error to the stack in case of a problem and continues to the next folder. So if we switch to exceptions the execution would just break off at that point which would not always be desirable. So perhaps this needs to be discussed a bit on how to deal with this in 3.0 As for now I think the changes made by dereuromark in the lastest commit to reset the lists by default when calling errros() and messages() should suffice and can be included in 2.3.'"
b"b' @ADmad True
column11: adding exceptions might take some more internal rebuilding of the Folder class then.  I agree that resetting on errors()/messages() is a good stop gap for now.'"

column10: b'b" 8th Oct 2013
column11: **[euromark]url  said: The main reason for me to address the current RSS output is that it\'s terribly verbose when trying to use namespaces. See [tests]url The global one would suffice
column12: but the way the helper generates the output (incremental XML building for each sub element) it needs the namespaces at every level for each and every element
column13: making the source code up to thousand times larger than it needs to be (for larger feeds).With a few extra namespaces this can get out of hand soon. I have been working on a leaner implementation that does also not involve helpers and view files:[RssView]url  ( [RssViewTest]url  ) It also:Simplifies the use of namespaces and their prefixes (auto-add only those that are actually used).Supporta CDATA (unescaped content) with a little trick as XML escapes it even though it shouldn\'t. But maybe a different solution
column14: using XML internal features
column15: would also be a good approach. Let me know what you think."'

column10: b'b" 9th Oct 2013
column11: **[Mark Story]url  said: I don\'t know if relying on specific view variable names is necessarily a good idea. It makes the controller + view coupled around the variable names. If there was a way to map existing view variables to the ones needed for RSS it might be better. It might also be hard to get view data in the shape required for rendering RSS
column12: it might be useful to either allow transformation functions to be set
column13: or require the use of a view file that does the transformation."'

b"b' Long subject lines break MailTransport'"

b'b\' This issue is a continuation of url // Currently this link died? I built CentOS and qmail server and reproduced this issue.CentOS 5.9Apache 2.2.3PHP 5.4.20CakePHP 2.4.1Qmail 1.03.5 case 1:CakeEmail -Outgoing SMTP packets have CRCRLF (at *1). case 2:CakeEmail -Message in mailbox has CRLF (at *2) . And some headers overflow to mail body in MUA (at *3). sendmail command which is wrapper of qmail requires LF text. (*4)url PHP must output LF text to \\\'sendmail_path\\\'. To output text with LF
column12: \\\'subject\\\'
column13: \\\'message\\\' and \\\'headers\\\' arguments of mail() must have LF.If \\\'to\\\' and \\\'subject\\\' have LF
column14: LF is converted to a SPACE(0x20) in mail() function.(*5) // If they have CRLF
column15: CRLF is passed to \\\'sendmail_path\\\' without change. And headers overflow to mail body. Current implementation:Use LF for EOL. Use CRLF to divide each subject and email header line.Fault: message has CRLF. Workaround:Use SmtpTransport.SMTP requires CRLF(RFC 5321).SmrpTransport uses CRLF for EOL. And mb_encode_mimeheader divides by CRLF. Solution 1 for MailTransport:Use LF for EOL.And use zero-length-string to divide each subject and email header line.Fault: There is a possibility of exceed 998 bytes(RFC 5322). Solution 2 for MailTransport:Use LF at all line break.Fault: LF in \\\'to\\\' and \\\'subject\\\' is replaced by SPACE(0x20). (*4)qmail requires LF.Postfix seems to judge CRLF or LF using end of line of line 1.Some POP3 servers replace like this: s/(CR)?/  It negates this issue. (*5) This is a strange behavior.CRLF[ |\\\\t]+ is passed through. LF[ |\\\\t]+ is not passed through. But mail() outputs "\\\\n" as header line break. This has been reported by user. But it is not modified until now. url  A patch for use LF at all line break.  \''

I worry that \'fixing\' delivery for Qmail will break other MTA\'s like postfix which do not have the same strange behavior that Qmail does. "'

Also avoids the need for any kind of preg_match looping to be able to know which behavior class to call preventing adding this feature from slowing things down even when it\'s not in use."'

b"b' 3.0 Split CSRF tokens out of SecurityComponent'"
b'b" While SecurityComponent is great
column11: the form tampering prevention features can be obtrusive if you just want CSRF protection. Splitting CSRF tokens into a separate component would allow developers to opt into just the features they need.#### Shared CSRF tokens In addition to splitting out the CSRF features
column12: I think adopting a per session CSRF token is a better default. As applications become more reliant on JavaScript and XHR
column13: managing onetime use tokens becomes painful. Using a CSRF token that is shared per session is the default in many other frameworks like Django and Rails
column14: and I see no reason why it shouldn\'t be our default as well.#### Tokens stored in COOKIE The new tokens should preferably be stored in a COOKIE
column15: this makes checking them simpler as developers don\'t need the additional dependency of starting a session to verify them.#### Accept X-CSRF-Token header In addition to accepting csrftokens via request body data
column16: it would be good to allow csrftokens to be submitted via a header field. This often makes it easier to send tokens in ajax based applications. See #1913 for more detail"'

Same is possible using an array directly (usually not possible without some malicious intend): But seeing passed params as a thing that will soon be gone anyway my main concern is regarding the "new " query It is already bad enough that PHP internally is not very type safe and we need to be careful how to treat variables. That we can manage
column24: though.But when data is coming from outside and from untrusty sources (in this case a faulty JS script
column25: a  engine or even a user with malicious intend) we should be better safe than sorry. Example of an implementation that is sure widely used: Ok
column27: but I bet there are other uses cases where that adjective would be suitable. And here what it would currently need quite the overhead: In this case restricting all query strings to scalar values would be the way to go.Specific query strings can be whitelisted to be allowed either array only or even both.If a querystring behaves incorrect
column28: it should throw an Exception and end up as 404. It would need to be part of the request object as this is mainly responsible for handling the data input.We could use a similar syntax as Auth and ALL key to set default values controller-wide and then can  specific query string types (whitelisting). For easy transition and BC I recommend to set the default to "both" right now in 2.5.It is fairly easy to overwrite the default then via AppController if desired (e.g. if some app exclusively uses strings here that would be a quick fix). And ideas on a more concrete implementation so far? I would love to see that going into the next minor release as part of an important step to restrict manipulation or triggering of wild behavior in Cake apps via query strings.\''

column10: b'b" It might make sense to just close this ticket if we plan on keeping DbAcl dead. I\'m personally all for removing the current Acl code. It is bad in a few different ways:It confuses the heck out of new developers.It is pretty limited in what it can do. For example it is totally unsuitable for row based ACL or anything finer than controller action based ACLs.There are better generic replacement libraries that do everything our Acl implementation did and much more."'

b"b' Implementing this new adapter should be fairly trivial:Create Cake\\\\Database\\\\Drive\\\\SqlServer and make it extend \\\\Cake\\\\Database\\\\Driver and use the PDODriverTrait
column11: implement the basic connection methodCreate a SqlServerDialectTrait and make the driver use it. The trait can implement the methods   and to alter the query object in any way required by the specific dialect. Since this one and Postgres both implement TSQL

b"b' 3.0 Refactor and rebuild the internals of FormHelper'"

b"b' FormHelper is an important and very complicated piece of CakePHP. FormHelper suffers from many of the same problems that PaginatorHelper did:Option bloat makes testing and documentation more complex.Features like multiple text boxes are mixed in with un-related code.God class FormHelper is an enormous class with an enormous test suite.Highly coupled to I think there are a number of opportunities to improve FormHelper and have started to outline the issues and possible solutions in [this wiki page]url ### Widgets to build[x] Checkbox[x] Radio[x] Select[x] Multi-checkbox[x] [x] Datetime (select based)[x] Label[x] CSRF field[x] File[x] Textarea[x] Button[x] Submit Higher level features like and would be combinations of the above.'"
b'b" We really should take our time to get this right
column11: I\'m sure we will benefit from it.Also I wouldn\'t try too hard to keep things the same for the developer
column12: just to make the migration easier.If there\'s need for a change to make things possible
column13: go that way even if will complicate the migration.CakePHP is a major release. Such a migration can (but doesn\'t have to) have some implications."'

But this i a necessary  is such a great framework because it can be used as it is but also you can fine tune many of its aspects. FormHelper should follow the same principle."'

column10: b'b" I think clientside validation is way outside of the scope formhelper should have. The JavaScript landscape is ever changing
column11: and I don\'t think we should waste time attempting to devise a solution that will have the world change around it. The extensible widget system would allow developers to replace the date widget with an html5 version if they wanted. The template system is pretty flexibleas well. You can see it in action in the paginator helper. I think it and the ability to replace or add custom widgets will allow developers the flexibility they need. Perhaps classnames are the one option we can keep for divs and labels. The current mess of attributes is simply not going to move forward. It is a nightmare to maintain
column12: test
column13: and document."'

column10: b"b' I like the idea of the templates and already started on this some time ago but then discontinued it. But for another reason: In a client project where the client wanted to display an insane amount of form inputs on the same page the form helper has turned out to be horrible slow. The whole page took ~3.5 sec to render AFAIR and 1/3 of the time was caused by the form helper alone. To disable the security component made it interestingly a lot faster the reason for that is some excessive use of one of the Hash class methods and the attribute building. It is unlikely that many apps have that many form inputs on one page but checking performance with 100
column11: 200 and 300 inputs on the same page is something worth to look at IMHO.'"

column10: b"b' Performance was a big reason I wanted to use string templates. I know for example the PaginatorHelper got ~2x faster with the switch to string templates over building HTML using arrays.'"

b"b' 3.0 Table delete'"

b'b" Implement the requirements outlined in #2259.  This set of changes adds entity deletion to the ORM for 3.0. Right now pivot table records are removed using deleteAll(). I could see an argument for loading and deleting the entities instead
column11: and I\'m happy to change the code around. Some questions I had:Should the association classes now how to delete associated records? For example should
column12: and contain the logic for removing  table records instead of putting it all in  . I think having it in the association allows user-land associations more flexibility in the future.I\'m not sure the code will work with multi-column primary keys yet. I think we will need to add a fixture set that includes multi-column primary keys so we can ensure saving & deleting associations with multi-column primary keys works. This may be the next logical block of work."'

column10: b"b' So I decided to go ahead and move the cascading delete logic into the association classes. I think this gives an overall cleaner approach that will afford flexible userland extensions as needed. It also keeps Table simpler and more focused.'"
b"b' I totally agree the cascading delete should be done in the association classes. Having multi column primary keys can be quite difficult to manage
column11: for what I see. Are we sure we still want to support them?'"

column10: b"b' I think multi column primary keys are important for multi-tenant applications. I think the tricky part of them will be figuring out how they should work in associations as join conditions become more complex.'"

b'b" @lorenzo I fixed up most of the issues you raised. I can\'t come up with a good name for the option name. In 2.x a similar option for hasMany was called \'exclusive\' which I think is a pretty bad name. Some ideas I had were:bulkDeletefastDelete But neither really strike me as great names."'
b'b" @markstory Think the only difference is that callback are fired
column11: so what about \'cascadeCallbacks\' ?"'

column10: b'b" The other big difference is N queries vs. 1. Using deleteAll() is way  for large datasets. Loading and looping will always be  expensive.  I think the name is reasonable though. I\'ll run with that for now."'
b"b' I added the cascadeCallback option and defaulted it to false. I thought choosing the more efficient option as a default made sense.'"
b"b' I think this is good to go :)'"

b'b" We always change things. Even new features. I think this is a good exception message worth being introduced in 2.5.Also note that this can be also seen as a fix for a better error reporting as the mime() method doesn\'t work without the functions available (just silently always returning false here seems wrong to me). Thus this is a vital message for 2.x to actually make use of this method."'
b'b" I\'m on @dereuromark\'s side even though I acknoledge that it can break an app that assumes the old behavior.But the change in behavior is a sensible one."'

column10: b"b' 3.0 get / update / save flow improvement'"

b"b' CakePHP 3.0 looks awesome and really promising! I spent some time reading through the docs and noticed something that I think could use usability improvement. In url  the flow of get / update / save is: Can I suggest two improvements:Can the first line be done automatically and dropped into  ?Can the be called on instead of on  ? The flow would be: Can the class extend the class?'"
b'b" Controllers still have the table with the same name as them assigned as a property. For example in the ArticlesController
column11: you would have access to similar to how you would in 2.x. There is also a method for loading other table objects and assigning them as properties. For example: will work. Is there somewhere in the documentation this could be clearer? While save & delete seem attractive on the entity class
column12: they introduce a bunch of dependencies that are tricky to manage. How would the following work for example: There isn\'t really a way to give the Article instance a copy of the table it needs to save into. We\'d either have to rely strictly on naming conventions
column13: or rely bi-directional configuration where both the entity class and table class need to know about each other. So far we\'ve avoided this by having the save() method only live on the table object. Why would entity extend Table? I don\'t think I understand the reasoning for adding inheritance there."'

column10: b'b" IMO
column11: introducing a Repository / Entity / Table is much more complex than a Model. All CakePHP users know MVC with a Model
column12: and that the ORM is a transparent layer between the table and the Model. If we can make this transparent to the user (developer)
column13: it would simplify things. What\'s wrong with naming conventions? Also
column14: the class would need access to the table class
column15: but why would the class need access to the class?  From my understanding
column16: represents a set of Entities. If we make extend
column17: then all of the exposed functionality will be through
column18: and would handle the behind-the-scenes work (maybe an Abstract Class). All the developer will need to think about is Entity."'

column10: b'b" There are 5 steps happening here:1. Loading the: Model (2.x) / Repository (3.x)2. Making the call: Model (2.x) / Table (3.x)3. Retrieving the results: Model (2.x) / Entity (3.x)4. Making changes: array (2.x) / Entity (3.x)5. Saving changes: Model (2.x) / Table (3.x) That\'s one big soup of Repositories
column11: Entities
column12: & Tables. If we keep all exposed methods to one class (Entity or Model)
column13: we can load (# 1)
column14: call (# 2)
column15: and retrieve (# 3)
column16: change (# 4)
column17: and save (# 5)."'

column10: b'b" I\'m happy to contribute to the code to make this happen."'
b'b" CakePHP helps you with this step
column11: by accessing $this->Articles it will load the table object by naming conventions. If you don\'t load a class for fetching records what else would you do?Well
column12: no matter if you choose ActiveRecord or our version of DataMapper
column13: you need to do those two steps.Also using ActiveRecord you would need to do the same
column14: right? The only difference for that workflow is more or less this line which is  larger than this If you think about it
column15: the difference is not that big. I will mention some reasons why ActiveRecord is not the default implementation:ActiveRecord requires you to always have a connection the database. Testing becomes much harder
column16: if you know rails
column17: then you know that was a very big discussion topic.ActiveRecord couples your domain logic to the repository :( What if you want to save the same structure from an entity into something like ElasticSearch?ActiveRecord classes become juggernauts
column18: I can see that from my current CakePHP apps and near all rails apps I\'ve seenActiveRecord is actually easy to implement on top of datamapper
column19: so it could be an additional and optional layer on top of what we have now.I\'ve never felt comfortable having objects in the view that are capable of finding
column20: saving or deleting data in the databaseIt\'s a complete mess to override
column21: if you look at other frameworks
column22: you will see that the plugins they release are usually locked to their ActiveRecord. Using plain objects and delegating the table responsibilities to another class is better for sharing code. With that said
column23: and if you want this to happen you could build the ActiveRecord layer. You will need to implement the following classes:   and would need to be applied to your entities at will. This could be offered as a separate plugin for people wanting a rails-like feeling in cakephp."'

column10: b'b" I\'m not suggesting to remove any of the steps only to keep it consistent to one class / object. That seems to be the class. Steps 1
column12: & 5 which operate on other classes
column13: can simply have wrapper methods in the class and be delegated to their respective classes. This keeps everything much simpler."'

column10: b'b" @josephzidell I don\'t think we can move save() down for the reasons outlined above. How would the entity find the table class it is connected to? I really dislike the ActiveRecord pattern personally. It seems great on the surface
column11: but the the conflation of concerns results in a few nasty things:1. Enormous classes with 100\'s of methods. We saw this in our old Model layer
column12: and it can be seen in the huge array of method Rails\' ActiveRecord class has. Similar issues exist in laravel and lithium.2. Pain to test and additional magic. ActiveRecord necessitates a certain amount of inferred magic and global state that I would prefer to avoid where ever possible."'

column10: b"b' There are passing test cases for MediaView. Digging into a potential bug in deprecated code is pointless. You are using cake 2.4.5 so just update your code to use the request object to render file as shown in manual.'"

b'b\' Wow.  Then let\\\'s pretend for the sake of argument that the test cases are not robust enough and there actually is a breaking bug in the MediaView.  The MediaView then goes beyond "depreciated" to "broken and will not fix".  In that case
column11: a note should be added to the cookbook and upgrade notes that applications using the MediaView _must_ be upgraded to the new file format. I\\\'d consider this a breaking bug because sending a file with an extra "1" at the end can cause many different files to be considered corrupt by their interpreters.  This is how I found the bug. Additionally
column12: this issue may extend beyond just the MediaView because there are other views that return true in certain cases as well.\''

column10: b'b\' A view class returning true is indeed problematic since [Controller::render()]url  sets the return value of it\\\'s render() method as response body (which would end up as "1" when echoed). So possible fixes are:View classes must not return true to indicate success.Controller::render() should not set return value from view class as response body if it\\\'s boolean. While we can fix the core classes there might be custom view classes out there which might be doing the same. So probably the second fix is more desirable (or both). @watermark My apologies for trying to dismiss the issue earlier.\''
b"b' Closing as #2785 has been merged.'"

column10: b"b' Transactions do not get rollbacked in saveAssociated'"
b"b' By default saveAssociated attempts to save the records in a single transaction. Additionally
column11: if a foreign key is violeted during this operation
column12: an exception is thrown. Now here is the problem: before the exception is thrown
column13: the transaction initiated by saveAssociated is never rollbacked
column14: thus making it impossible to save further records after the exception is thrown.  The expected behaviour: any transaction started  by the  framework should be either committed or rollbacked always-'"

column10: b"b' Did you use atomic=true? From what I remember that will enable rollbacks.'"
b"b' true is the default value.'"
b"b' Indeed it is
column11: but there is a missing  around the various save operations to handle exceptions from PDO.'"

b"b' Invocations not being verified properly when using manually instantiated mocks'"
b'b\' I\\\'ve just stumbled over this by chance in the
column11: using CakePHP 2.4.5 and PHPUnit 3.7.32. I haven\\\'t checked other tests yet where the mocks are used the same way. The problem is that all these expected invocations set via are only verified when they are actually being invoked
column12: not if they have been invoked at all. Remove for example the call in the test method
column13: you should see that the test still passes fine
column14: even though none of the expected methods were actually invoked. This means that in case something would go wrong and cause methods to not be invoked
column15: then the tests might not catch that. This stems from using a manually instantiated mock: It\\\'s working as expected when using the mock object returned from  : I\\\'ve tried to locate the problem
column16: and if I got this correctly
column17: then the "problem" is that PHPUnit will only verify those mock objects after the test run
column18: that were instantiated in
column19: ie those added to  . Except for the tests that would (seemingly correctly) fail otherwise
column20: is there a reason why the tests are using manually instantiated mocks? The failing tests are easy to fix
column21: except for
column22: it looks like it doesn\\\'t take parameters into account as expected
column23: seems the matcher only matches the invoke count of the specified method regardless of the specified parameters
column24: and the parameters are then being evaluated separately
column25: not sure whether that\\\'s a PHPUnit bug or the expected behavior.\''

column10: b'b" I think you will find better answer in the phpunit IRC or their issue tracker. Those are features specific to the testing framework. I will close this ticket as I don\'t think we can accurately answer those doubts."'
b'b" @lorenzo That\'s probably true
column11: but beside these doubts there are actually problems with CakePHP
column12: namely the tests not being done properly as described
column13: which I think is something that should be addressed. I just tried to additionally figure out the underlying cause in PHPUnit as it might be of help for  around these problems :)"'

column10: b"b' What we have in our test suite was purposefully done that way. We are well aware of how mocks work. The example you cite contains a matcher for connect
column11: which means
column12: that the test does not actually care if the method was called or not
column13: it only cares about the rest of the expectations. Whether that was the right thing to do for that test
column14: it is another topic
column15: probably a would have been a better suit'"

column10: b'b" Sure

column14: in the wrong order
column15: etc. I also tried to dig a little deeper in the PHPUnit code
column16: and now I\'m pretty sure that it\'s really the use of the additionally manually instantiated mock. After the test has be run is being invoked

column10: b'b" Note I think the underlying issue
column11: I was trying to fix was Controller and other things specifically RequestHandler
column12: overriding View variables by default
column13: which leads to View variable default being essentially meaningless: Let Controller  a proxy for View state
column14: but don\'t override the  View\'s default with Controller defaults."'

column10: b'b" Note
column11: I actually don\'t think this is great solution
column12: just a bit better. I would prefer to see View decoupled from Controller. As it stands Controller acts as a proxy for view state which is ~fine. Except that Controller clobbers View\'s default settings with its own default setting on construction. IMO if you want to provide view switching
column13: you should have to provide a subclass of View and define whatever default view layout path
column14: view path
column15: file extension
column16: etc in there and not get RequestHandler involved let it just switch the view class and respect the new view classes defaults. I might create a related ticket for this
column17: but I still think above is a bit cleaner and worth having in."'

column10: b"b' Seems reasonable to me. It would also free us up from having as much view related configuration in the controllers. I personally think that view subclasses are an under utilized aspect of CakePHP and perhaps having a separate layoutless AjaxView would help people understand that more. It also simplifies RequestHandlerComponent considerably.'"
b"b' @markstory great to hear you agree :). I created a ticket about the decoupling Controller and View #2970 '"
b"b' Great
column11: I think once we figure the view subclass ideas out this will b easier to move forward with.'"

column10: b"b' Controller view vars. Refs #2970.'"

b'b" Rewrite of the way Controller passes View vars to view on  construction. Refs #2970. NOTE: this ticket originally proposed deprecating setting view options on Controller and instead  providing a setter method or  . This was to avoid Controller clobbering View\'s default fields
column11: which essentially made the default values in View or any subclass meaningless. On review this PR still aims to address the clobbering issue but does not deprecate setting view options on Controller and  does not add said setter method. View Options are now only passed to the View if explicitly set on Controller. The View constructor also changes to: The other minor change is that the protected Controller::_getViewObject() is now a public View factory called Controller::createView(). This is how you should now create a View that relies on defaults set in a controller (not  ). Deprecating setting view options on controller may be addressed later in a another ticket."'

column10: b'b" I just pushed a commit reverted [set]ViewOptions()
column11: and just setting the view options directly on Controller but passing them over to the View differently such that View default are not clobbered. I think this is the most practical approach as BWC with setting view vars on Controller would likely have to be maintained
column12: and its confusing and ~messy to implement having two ways to set View vars from the controller. Note there is still one failing test I cant figure out
column13: but thought I\'d push early for . Sorry haven\'t had time to try and bring this to some conclusion till now. "'

b"b' 3.0 Console improvements'"

b'b" The cake console has been iteratively improved in each of the major CakePHP releases. There are still a few opportunities to improve the console for 3.0.### CLI bootstrap file in app skeleton CLI context is often different from web context. Logging will be different
column11: and additional cli command bootstrapping code may need to be loaded. To this end
column12: an empty file could be included in the app skeleton. This would give an easy place for developers to hook their CLI only logic into.### Options and argumentsArgs passed to shell methods The non-option arguments for console commands should be passed to the shell methods like controller actions.The
column14: and options are no longer required. Since CakePHP 3.0 won\'t have shared libraries these arguments become less important and mostly bloat.  methods will get positional arguments passed to their methods. Options will be available on  . The and options are used as a convention to control the output level of console commands.### Subcommand handling Currently CakePHP makes every public method callable from the terminal. Much like controllers this is a balance of ease of use and being explicit. Currently the console libraries have no way of hiding public actions. A possible improvement would be to leverage the existing subcommands in the option parsers.If a shell has no defined subcommands
column15: all public methods can be called from the terminal.If a shell defines subcommands
column16: only those  will be callable.  If a subcommand could match a task name
column17: or a public method
column18: the Task will be called. Tasks will have their main() called when they are set as a subcommand.  Tasks invoked as subcommands will have positional arguments sent to their main() method.Tasks cannot be directly called unless they are exposed through subcommands.### Command names and aliases By default the existing routing would be used for  commands. However
column19: plugin or app shells can define shorter command aliases. Connected aliases would be looked at _only if_ matching an  shell fails. For example: This would enable to be callable. If however
column20: an application defines an shell
column21: that shell will be used instead. Aliased shells can still be invoked from their original name as well. The aliased forms would also be output by the CommandListShell.### Automatic aliasing and shortest  handling In addition to manual aliasing
column22: CakePHP could automatically alias plugin shells as long as they do not conflict with  shells. If two plugins would result in the same alias being generated
column23: neither will be aliased. In addition to automatic aliases
column24: shell names
column25: and subcommands would support being run via their shortest unambiguous name. For example would point to in a default installation. This short form handling would work for both shell names
column27: enabling to run  .### Tasks[x] Remove old flags.[x] Make Shell methods get positional arguments.[x] Add to app skeleton.[x] Add alias() method.[x] Rework how subcommands work.[x] Rename Task::execute() to Task::main() so it is consistent with Shell.[x] Automatic shell aliasing."'

column11: my login  is broken
column12: leading to a blackhole error. I\\\'m embedding a login form with action attribute set to "url " in a http view to ensure the login credentials get posted over https. From what I can see in FormHelper::create()
column13: a full url containing protocol
column14: hostname and action set in $options[\\\'url\\\'] finds its way into $this->_lastAction without modifications. However
column15: in SecurityComponent::_validatePost()
column16: the according url to be compared is read from $this->request->here() which doesn\\\'t contain protocol and hostname. This results in the hashes not being identical and the form submission being rejected. Is it no longer possible to render a form with full https protocol + hostname + action within a http view
column17: or shouldn\\\'t the  part always be removed before setting $this->_lastAction by FormHelper::create()? Or is there another way I\\\'m not aware of to ensure posting a form to https even if the form is rendered in a http page
column18: without using full  its action attribute?\''

column10: b'b" I can only assume the slowness comes from metadata reflection.  In 3.0
column11: the cache expiration doesn\'t auto-toggle based on debug anymore. And the default expiry is 10 seconds. That easily explains why the ORM is fast and then slow as you hit an empty cache. A few options would be to re-introduce the cache expiry time shifting for and based on
column12: or make the default cache time longer."'

column10: b'b" The first find() triggers metadata reflection
column11: I\'ve often thought it might be nice to have a shell command to seed a cache with the required model metadata. It might make deployments a bit easier as you can seed the cache after migrations but before deploying new code."'

column16: I find it very fast once the metadata is cached so anything to work around this I think is a positive step forward. Given that the metadata needs to be cached for a long time to prevent it from recaching and going slow again

b"b' Router::connect() interprets CamelCased plugins fine but causes Missing Controller if redirected'"
b'b\' If I\\\'m in a plugin and do a redirect() to a controller in the same plugin
column11: but not be explicit about the plugin
column12: it uses the Camelized version of the plugin (as per $this->request->params[\\\'plugin\\\'])
column13: while the default router parsing () uses the under_score version of the plugin in the url parsing.  If the current URL is /
column14: and it redirects via $this->redirect(array(\\\'controller\\\'=>\\\'posts\\\'))  Then the url it goes to is / The routing table (due to ) only interprets the under_scored plugin names
column15: ie /
column16: and thus it interprets "Blog" as the controller instead of the plugin. This is version 2.5.1
column17: I just upgraded. It\\\'s not a problem if you specifically say $this->redirect(\\\'plugin\\\'=>\\\'blog\\\'
column18: \\\'controller\\\'=>\\\'posts\\\')) I would say if it\\\'s going to interject the plugin at all as a default parameter
column19: then it should do it properly. Make a proper assumption. Maybe I\\\'m doing something wrong?\''

column10: b'b\' The problem seems to be a route I had: Router::connect("/"
column11: array(\\\'plugin\\\'=>\\\'Blog\\\'
column12: \\\'controller\\\'=>\\\'topics\\\'
column13: \\\'action\\\'=>\\\'index\\\')); Because the plugin is CamelCased
column14: it still serves the page
column15: but then $this->request->params[\\\'plugin\\\'] is tainted with a value that won\\\'t properly be caught by the router once you do a redirect(). I would say that if for some reason $this->request->params[\\\'plugin\\\'] happens to become CamelCased (in the case of explicitly doing so in Router::connect() or Router::url() )
column16: then it should sanitize it first
column17: so the default routing (that only uses under_scored plugin names) catches it properly. If the controller can be CamelCased in the URL and still work
column18: ie array(\\\'plugin\\\'=>\\\'blog\\\'
column19: \\\'controller\\\'=>\\\'Posts\\\')
column20: shouldn\\\'t the plugin name work as well if CamelCased? Basically
column21: the "Missing Controller" issue could also mean that the plugin was CamelCased
column22: when the default routing doesn\\\'t interpret that. I find it confusing
column23: especially when it will interpret the controller name CamelCased or under_scored with no difference.\''

column10: b'b\' If we\\\'re getting in the spirit of CamelCasing everything
column11: shouldn\\\'t we have the default routes properly interpret a url such as "/" to go to the  ? \''

column10: b'b" Route parameters are always underscored historically. Since the issue was in the routes you wrote
column11: I don\'t see an issue here. I\'m not sure automatically converting request parameters is a good idea
column12: as it can cause issues with action names that are camelBacked. Accepting multiple URL\'s is something the default routes do to help with rapid application development
column13: but it is often not a recommended practice for applications where SEO matters
column14: as it can cause duplicate content issues with webcrawlers."'

column10: b"b' I think we should revisit this in 3.0
column11: specially when generating links there is no reason why you cannot provide the actual name of the controller instead of having to inflect it'"

column10: b"b' Perhaps router could inflect only the controller and plugin keys? '"
b"b' Yup
column11: the router should be the layer taking care if that'"

column10: b"b' Automatic inflection would also need to be done as routes are connected so all the keys match.'"
b'b" If both / and / are going to work
column11: I really don\'t see any reason why / shouldn\'t work as well. Other than historical convention
column12: is there any real reason why the default routing needs to use under_scored plugin names in the URL pattern matching? Can\'t it just CamelCase the plugin before trying to match it
column13: as it seems to do with the controller (since the URL can just as easily use an under_scored controller name)? Actions can stay as is
column14: I\'d never expect otherwise....(and if someone really wants to stick with CamelCase
column15: they can create method names that follow the syntax)"'

column10: b'b" Controller names are converted to CamelCase in order to match the classname. Plugin names are matched with a regexp pattern which currently doesn\'t include CamelCase versions. If it did
column11: we might run int issues with ambiguous routes."'

column10: b"b' Route camel casing was addressed in a previous PR. This should work now'"

column10: b"b' I think exceptions **should** be thrown when an application is expecting encrypted data and does not get it. To me not throwing an exception voids the entire point of encrypted cookies. For example:I have a cookie with sensitive data
column11: that the client should not tamper with
column12: so I encrypt it.If an attacker can figure out the general structure of the data
column13: they can simply replace the encrypted cookie with a plaintext one and easily defeat any and all protections my application may get from encrypting the cookie.'"

column10: b"b' I agree exceptions should be thrown when encryption is expected. But there are plenty sources a cookie can come from
column11: for example those set from javascript. Maybe having a list of the cookies you expect to read would help?'"

column10: b"b' What if cookie data is lazily read as keys are accessed? That would fix the issues around decrypting all the cookies.'"
b"b' I like that even more'"
b"b' Ok
column11: I can work on making that happen. In hindsight eagerly reading and decrypting all the cookies on every request is pretty wasteful.'"

column10: b"b' Closing again as #3827 introduces lazy cookie decryption which solves the issues described here around eagerly decrypting cookie data.'"

column10: b'b" QueryExpression don\'t get closures"'
b'b" I made some Query: If we pass directly closure as parameter to Query::where() or Query::andWhere() then Query::_conjugate() method runs: and closure is executed. But if we pass closure in array
column11: then it isn\'t called in _conjugate() method
column12: and it is passed into QueryExpression::add() as parameters.Then is called QueryExpression::_addConditions() method which iterate parameters.There is checking types of parameter items
column13: but checking closure is missed.I personally added some modification: After this fix
column14: all closure expressions are executed and added into query chain."'

b'b\' CakeResponse::sharable not setting "max-age" header\''

b'b\' url will set The problem with this is that s-maxage applies only to shared caches (e.g. proxies).  It is not respected by browsers. In my tests the resource keeps getting fetched (skipping my browser cache) even though this header is present. If I call  after sharable()
column11: this changes the header to  and at this point my browser starts using the browser cache instead of trying the server. Tested via Chrome devtools: "Status Code:200 OK (from cache)" Specs:url \''

column10: b"b' The method has two modes. One mode sets the public cache headers (the mode you are using). The other sets the private cache headers. If you want both the public + private set
column11: you should use: Alternatively you can call sharable() and maxAge() like you currently are. Closing as the function is working properly when used as documented.'"

b"b' Cake\\\\Utility\\\\Time using current time in DATE fields. '"
b'b" Unlike strings
column11: when we\'re getting a DATE or DATETIME field from MySQL it becomes a Time object
column12: right?   is a DATE type data. It doesn\'t have time and CakePHP is using the present time
column13: making the original value change every second
column14: unless we format it to ignore time
column15: we\'re working with wrong data."'

column10: b"b' This new method works exactly the same as the old  . It has always HTML escaped its output.'"
b"b' Is it intended behavior? I guess when cake used named parameters (var:ffff) it made sense. Now it forces users to use Router::url'"
b'b" @markstory Haven\'t _fully_ considered the consequences
column11: but _not_ HTML-escaping could actually make sense. Maybe the escaping should be the responsibility of the Helper _consuming_ the URL
column12: e.g.  . This allows (for example) a Helper for \'Plain text\' to use a different  than helpers for HTML. Additionally
column13: I think that [ ]url  _already_ html escapes attribute-values by default
column14: so this could be double. (Haven\'t checked the complete flow) People passing a URL as a _string_ to helpers
column15: probably won\'t pass it as a HTML-escaped string either
column16: so treating them both the same way would reduce the number of different paths to \'walk\'"'

column10: b"b' @thaJeztah Can you provide an _actual_ e.g. of a problem this escaping creates?'"
b'b" @ADmad I don\'t think there\'s a direct _problem_ here
column11: my comment if more about consistency and (possibly) reducing overhead. I can delve more deeply into this when I\'m behind my computer. Let me get back to you
column12: then I\'ll try to make my point clear. Please do not see my comment as critique
column13: purely as an attempt to improve the code base :smile:"'

column10: b"b' @RobertMeisner Currently yes it is intended
column11: as path segments or query string parameters could contain HTML special characters that would need escaping in an HTML context.'"

column10: b"b' @thaJeztah If you think things can be improved feel free to submit a patch.'"
b'b" @ADmad Will do. I lost track a bit of the development of CakePHP 3 (very busy at work)
column11: but trying to keep up now. I\'ve seen some minor improvements that I might create a pull request for if I find some time this week. If I\'m not behind my computer
column12: I might give some feedback on PRs now and then :smile:"'

column10: b"b' Closing as I think escaping urls is a sane default. If you think it can be improved just open a pull request :)'"

column10: b'b" I\'m giving this a +1. CTI would be a really cool feature
column11: and could actually fit in lots of apps (mine for sure :smile: ). If I may
column12: what I dislike most of the Doctrine implementation is that the topmost class in the hierarchy must know about all of its descendants (which looks a bit like a design flaw
column13: to me): any hopes this will be different in CakePHP\'s future implementation?"'

column10: b'b" @fquffio I\'ve not put much thought into this yet. If the parent didn\'t explicitly know about the child types
column11: how would they be discovered."'

column10: b'b\' @markstory I thought that maybe descendants\\\' existence could be notified to some "ambassador" (TableRegistry?) in the bootstrap
column11: instead of being hardcoded in the parent. Hence
column12: the topmost class should only be aware of which is the name of the discriminator column (if any)
column13: then query the ambassador to discover which is the correct child type based on the discriminator column\\\'s value when retrieving results. In the same fashion
column14: this "ambassador" would be responsible for returning the correct value to populate discriminator column when inserting new records
column15: and so on. I guess a similar approach could work for CTI as well as STI
column16: but probably it could be hard to deal with chains of inheritance (B extends A
column17: C extends B
column18: \\xe2\\x80\\xa6). My point is: personally
column19: I would like to be able to add new descendants in a plugin
column20: without having to edit the application\\\'s core code. For instance
column21: I might have a CakesTable that extends my BakeryProductsTable in the core application
column22: then add a CookiesTable that extends BakeryProductsTable as well in an optional plugin of which the core app might even be unaware of: having the list of descendants hardcoded in the BakeryProductsTable (see Doctrine\\\'s impl.) would be quite a problem
column23: in such a case. :wink:\''

column10: b"b' The registration approach would only work if the descendants were loaded on each request. Because PHP only loads the files that are used in a request
column11: not all the descendants will be loaded during bootstrap and the parent class would not know about their existence. If the descendant registration could be modified at runtime
column12: then both hardcoded and runtime registration through event notifiers could be afforded. For example the [API proposed by @robertpustulka]url  should allow both kinds of use cases.'"

column10: b'b" I\'ve been mulling on this a bit more. I\'ve put my thoughts [into a wiki page]url  If it makes it easier for others
column11: I can start a new RFC issue."'

column10: b"b' @markstory an RFC where we can discuss it will be better.'"
b'b" @lorenzo here\'s a start i guess: url should i open a PR? should it be a plugin or part of core?"'
b'b\' **Abstract: HasOne + PHP Class Inheritance / Aspects To me STI
column11: CTI
column12: HasOne
column13: IS A and HasAspect all seem to solve the same thing creating models that are similar and re-use behavior setups
column14: finders
column15: entity
column16: custom data types
column17: etc. Instead of strict "OO" inheriantance I tend to favour composition through aspects.The closest thing available
column18: we got is HasOne associations
column19: which is very similar to CTI
column20: already.Could HasOne handling be improved to do what STI and CTI trys to do
column21: here? Gather use cases of STI and CTI and see if we can wrap that around ? UsersTable HasOne ProfilesTableAdminUsersTable extends UsersTableAdminUsersTable HasOne AdminUsersPrivilegesTable A user then has a profileAn admin then has a profile and a privilege (users table
column22: user_profiles table
column23: admin_user_privileges table) Benefit: Normalized data
column24: easy to extend
column26: remove. Clear what\\\'s what by design in both sql tables and php classes.Drawback: JoinsSolution: support optional (materialized) views with refreshes and custom indicies. This will create denormalized data if you _need_ it for speed  ease of querying. If there is a need to just have a discriminator column
column27: could we add RDBMS agnostic ENUM support and improve  custom methods for polymorphic behavior? About STI and CTI: STI: url (+) No SQL JOINs required(+) Slow on RDBMS growth once you do a lot of table classes off one "real table" and use
column28: group by etc unless you add a lot of indicies (basically one per STI?).(+) Consistent without hassle across reads and writes.(-) Breaks with normalization goals of entities in .(-) Creates NULL values for specific fields by design.(-) Makes it hard to see just from the table which columns are utilized by what .(-) As the new ORM is very close to SQL
column29: what would select() do if you select columns that are (-) You need to explicitly define the fields that specify a model instead of getting it through the (-) Confuses the table name for table classes (cause for now by default Table class ~== rdbms table)(-) By design does not automatically inherit behaviors
column32: custom datatypes CTI: url (+) Does not break with normalization goals of entities in RDBMS(+) Does not create NULL values by design.(-) Some Impact on the RDBMS
column34: this can be improved by (materialized) views with indicies(-) Not necessarily consistent across  (non materialized SQL views)\''

column10: b'b\' @markstory May I ask why you dropped your plans for CTI? :disappointed: With STI only the dynamic registration pre-documented in the wiki (which seems great to me!) becomes IMHO much less useful: if an application is so "agnostic" that it requires plugins to self-register as "extensions" of some Model
column11: I think it is also quite likely that plugins will be kind enough to use separate tables to store their specific data
column12: instead of changing the schema of the main table
column13: as that could lead to possible conflicts and undesired behaviors. Am I that wrong? :grin: \''

column10: b"b' @fquffio I am not sure if class-table will make it into 3.3
column11: but I figured we could start with single-table and go from there.'"

b"b' SqLite tries to insert NULL values into NOT NULL fields.'"
b"b' When saving just city field this occurs: As you can see from url  the tests for Mysql pass just fine.Also
column11: when debugging the input prior to saving it is clear that non of the fields in question are marked as dirty or are touched in any way. The sql going into the Connection class looks fine
column12: as well. So for some reason SqLite takes all schema fields that are not part of the created record and tries to insert them as NULL which will fail for all NOT NULL fields
column13: of course.Maybe it should check the schema and apply an empty string where necessary instead.'"

column10: b"b' Please include the generated SQL for the failing queries.'"
b'b" I\'m -1 on this. I suspect MySQL is passing the tests because it silently ignores not-null constraints and automatically substitutes them with empty strings (or
column11: for a date field with
column12: which is even worse). I think that this test also fails on PostgreSQL and SQL Server? Basically
column13: MySQL is _wrong_ here; after all
column14: marking a field as means it is a required field
column15: so trying to insert a record without that field set
column16: **must** fail to guarantee data-integrity. CakePHP _could_ instead automatically generate and perform validation-rules based on the schema and invalidate the record before attempting to save it to the database."'

column10: b'b\' Here I\\\'m missing a "convention" ;-) What about?1. The root folder is for "low level" and "public" stuff e.g. /log(s) / tmp /assets (js
column11: css
column12: img)
column13: /bin and /vendor2. The /scr (or better /app) is for the "application layer"e.g. Controller
column14: Models
column15: Views
column16: Templates
column17: Locales
column18: Config
column19: Tests
column20: (App-)Plugins and so on.. I know this "proposal" would cause some changes. :-) Here are a few other thoughts:The root folder should be the "real" root folder of the web app.All public but secret folder must be protected with .htaccess (deny from all)I would prefer renaming the "src" folder back to "app" because it contains the whole "app logic"  and it\\\'s NOT a library like the vendor folder.  url Don\\\'t mix vendor with plugin folder on the same level.  This is confusing. For me a Plugin is more a "App plugin" and belongs to the "/app". Better move /plugin to /.I see some mixing of singular with plural again. e.g. vendor
column21: logs
column22: tmp
column23: plugins. Why is there no "convetion"? When to name a folder singular or plural? Woul\\\'d it be easier with singular?\''

column10: b'b\' I very much doubt it\\\'ll make it\\\'s way into 3.0 but we did discuss the possibility of "console routes" i.e changing the way shell dispatching works to be similar to web dispatching. That would address this particular concern and a fair bit more.\''

b'b" When extensively using the shell to create semantically easy to remember subcommands it would desirable to be able to use reserved words. I\'m resorting to using alternative names but it\'s weird sometimes. An easy solution would be to use method names with the pattern doXXXX: doList()
column11: doNew()
column12: ... I also like this because shell subcommand methods would be easily distinguishable from internal methods."'

column10: b'b\' Or
column11: if we ever rename controller actions to what other frameworks use
column12: including a suffix Action: "indexAction"
column13: we could then also suffix the commands like "listCommand". This would also more clearly differentiate those actions and commands from other (protected) class methods. Reactivates url  ;)\''

column10: b'b\' Differentiating those methods by name isn\\\'t the goal
column11: and it can be argued that it\\\'s a poor coding practice. I suggested it just because the way the current parser works
column12: it\\\'s maybe the simplest approach using only inferred names (no new options). Actually
column13: I like @bravo-kernel suggestion
column14: but @markstory\\\'s answer made me think it wasn\\\'t good to add a new option for this. I don\\\'t think I\\\'ve really understood the question: "How would any new options work with inferred command names where there is no option parser step involved?". b"b' Model::bindModel removes associations'"

b"b' If you bind a model on-the-fly and execute a query then the related model losses its associations.  Below is an unit test failing because of this issue. You should use two models with the following requirements:Comment belongs to PostPost has 1+ belongsTo relationship(s) Running on Cake 2.5.6 Is it the intended behavior?'"
b"b' This is expected behavior. By default association bound on the fly are reset after a find call. Set the second param to to false if you want to prevent that.'"
b"b' You mean the expected behavior is that the association of both models are reset after the find call?'"
b"b' I think you misread the ticket @ADmad He wants to tmp bind the modelBut it seems there is cross contamination of associated and involved models and their relations.'"
b"b' Ah sorry
column11: guess i did misread.'"

column10: b"b' @felixmaier1989 What happens if you do another fresh init() call? Are the relations then restored at least?  '"
b'b" The issue is that temporary bindings and contain do not work well together. They both manipulate the same keys and the \'temporary\' bindings that you set
column11: are then made permanent by \'containable\' as it too modifies the associations temporarily. I don\'t think there is a reasonable way to fix this as containable is just an abstraction around bindModel()."'

b'b\' Add support for disabling of the "existing" check on save\''

b"b' Sometimes you may wish to save a record with a set primaryKey without doing the check if it exists. An example is if I am importing data into my database with pre-set ids. Skipping the check would save a select query for each data item
column11: which can shorten the import a considerable amount for many records (We are importing around 5 million records from a legacy database) This adds a save option for skipping the check.'"

column10: b'b" What table\'s schema would you look in?  The problem with using the Table\'sschema is that you don\'t know which table to look in to search for amatching key field.  The reason we\'re searching for it is because it wascreated without the conventions
column11: so we\'re not able to infer the table bythe key field name (if it were instead eg. user_id)  We needinformation_schema because it allows us to search it\'s KEY_COLUMN table bycolumn_name
column12: showing us which table this key exists in. In looking into CakeSchema
column13: it looks like the ::read() method builds a listof all table objects for the schema in the give connection
column14: complete withcolumns and indexes.  That would be a preferable approach as it would workfor any driver (not just MySQL).  I\'ll check that out. DJ On Wed

column10: b'b" This may be an unintended consequence of trying to unify how cookie data is handled. In 2.x you could  easily get into a spot where deleting or updating data wouldn\'t always work. I think there is a pretty simple solution to this where we can bypass Hash::insert() if there are no in the $name."'
b"b' Fixed with #6173'"
b"b' Thanks!'"

b'b" The root cause of this issue is that the CookieComponent in 3.x stores all the data for a cookie keyspace as a single cookie. In 2.x each top level key was a separate cookie value sometimes depending on how you wrote the cookie data. I\'m not sure there is a fix that doesn\'t also compromise totally opaque encrypted cookie data unfortunately."'
b'b" Thanks @markstory
column11: that makes sense to me. If it\'s just not possible without compromising security
column12: then I\'d say this issue can be closed since it\'s really just an issue of upgrading from 2 to 3. I\'ll let you guys decide its fate
column13: though."'

column10: b'b" I\'ve started working on this and noticed this:I don\'t think the auth code should be coupled with the component registry in any way. It is used in BaseAuthenticate
column11: BaseAuthorize and DigestAuthenticate but it is only set to the _registry property and nothing else is done with it.I\'ve checked all adapters for their use of request / response. Response is not used anywhere. While I think it\'s OK to pass request AND response I don\'t think the auth system should be coupled with anything else. My problem now is I\'m not sure how to pass the needed objects the best way. Dependency injection would be nice in this case but we don\'t have it in the core. A possibility might be to pass a single object or an array of objects to the adapters and try to authenticate / authorize them. If a specific adapter requires for example the component registry it could iterate over the objects and pick the one that is the registry object or return false if it won\'t find a suitable object. Here is a proof of concept I\'m working on url  the unit test I\'ve written for that passes
column12: the user gets authenticated. But I haven\'t solved the problems discussed in the paragraph before. Maybe you have some better ideas how to do this?"'

column10: b'b" BasicAuthentication used to use the response to set challenge headers
column11: its since been refactored to use an exception. Having the response is useful if a userland authentication integration needs to render specific error pages
column12: or other response data that doesn\'t fit into an exception."'

b"b' About how Validation and Save work in CakePHP 3 ORM'"
b'b" Hi there
column11: I\'ve just started learning (and using) the new Cake3 ORM and I\'m pretty confused about the way entities
column12: save and validation work altogether. Assume we have some validations set in  . Amongst them: If I execute the following code in  :
column13: to my surprise
column14: the entity **WILL** be saved and there will be no errors printed.  On the other hand
column15: if we execute the following code:
column16: entity will **NOT** be saved (as it would be expected). I know validation is executed in or as a first measure. What shocks me is validation is not executed again in
column17: making modified fields bypass validation. I also know there\'s this Request Validation vs Application Rules separation now
column18: but there\'s not a lot of documentation about what you can and can\'t achieve with Application Rules (which leads to think this is not a case for Application Rules). So
column19: basically
column20: what is the approach one should take in all this?It is weird and should be fixed?_Repatch_ the Entity after modifying it (or be forced to _repatch_ always instead of modifying)
column21: and then call  ? (the attractiveness of having built an ORM decreases a lot here)Build these validations in the Application Rules instead? Thanks for your time!"'

column10: b'b" No. If your application is making changes to entities after they\'ve been built
column11: I would recommend using patchEntity() to do those changes if you need data type validations done. Application rules are used to ensure consistency before saving. The thinking behind splitting validation and consistency checks is as follows. Generally unsafe data comes from the user
column12: while internal application logic generally will not use incorrectly  data. Therefore
column13: validation is most useful when entities are created from user data. By validating data before it is converted into an entity
column14: we can not copy invalid data into an entity and prevent many inconsistent states before a save is event attempted."'

column10: b'b" Splitting validation
column11: makes sense
column12: but
column13: from my point of view
column14: it makes no sense not validating data passed to DB. I don\'t really care if the data was introduced by a user
column15: or a developer... An ORM that allows wrong data be in the DB... doesn\'t really sounds as it should be."'

column10: b'b\' So
column11: basically
column12: when we are defining validations in the model
column13: we are actually defining user input validation now. I would understand this if the Application Rules feature offered the same range of built-in validations
column14: but I think it doesn\\\'t (easily). A way to ensure every persisted Entity is fully consistent (wherever its data comes from) is not that crazy thing. The way it\\\'s built now easily allows invalid entities to be persisted. Long-time Cake developers are not used to this
column15: and shit is probably gonna happen. For those interested in emulating the old Cake behaviour
column16: you can maybe do this in your class: **EDIT: This patch below turned out not to be a good solution
column17: since will be never be executed if the entity already had errors. So
column18: basically
column19: setting entity properties after a "failed" or would result in those properties not being validated anyway.**  (shittiest solution ever
column20: I know). @markstory do you think this patch could have any side-efect (performance aside)? **EDIT: as mentioned above
column21: not a good solution.**\''

column10: b'b" @nigeon You can always use patchEntity() to modify entities
column11: or use  to implement the re-validation. It seems strange to me that the internals of an application would create invalidate states that would fail validation. For me the validation that is done in newEntity()/patchEntity() should be used to check data format and data types. Application rules should be used to do tasks like making sure email address are unique or that internal state machines are correct.  If there are gaps in the application rules features
column12: I think we can look at ways to improve that once we\'ve uncovered what those gaps are."'

column10: b'b" @nigeon If you come across ways that the application rules could be improved I bet others would be interested in those improvements as well. There are many other ORMs that don\'t provide validation or domain rules at all. Doctrine and SQLAlchemy are two that come to mind. Because of this we thought that our decisions to include both albeit slightly differently than we have in the past was an improvement."'

b'b" I know that this issue is closed but I want to add some words to the discussion that maybe helps to rethink this subject.  One the things that I loved about cakephp 3 was the new _ORM & Database Access_
column11: I understand and I do like the way application rules and validation rules were split. But (yeah
column12: there is a but) I think **when** those rules are checked is to be reviewed.I would list some points I\'ve been thinking on this matter:1. It\'s a bit confused and not very intuitive to check validation rules as soon as data is assigned
column13: and very often you would modify this data before you save it.2. It\'s not the way it works on cakephp 2
column14: I know that many things don\'t
column15: but it\'s less intuitive for those that migrate.3. Not always the data to build entities comes from forms
column16: or from users data
column17: it\'s very common to save related data that are build from other services (gis data
column18: ip
column19: ua
column20: etc.)
column21: or data that needs to be processed before you save it. I think that
column22: in this particular case
column23: it\'s great to having the chance to work directly upon an entity
column24: taking advantage of working with objects. Right now we should do it on an array
column25: and then pass it to or methods
column26: because those only accept an array as new data (if I am right). 4. Many times we hear that a good programming practice is to having methods that do what they claim to do
column27: neither nor are very good in this aspect. It\'s not very easy to guess that they will validate the data
column28: and already less intuitive that some data may get lost and not be there (on the entity). 5. Finally
column29: we don\'t have a method on Table Objects
column30: to validate in a explicit way
column32: the solution? Beside thinking about the weak points of this approach
column33: I been thinking on some possible solutions.  We already have an option for and to disable validation
column34: as have an option on method to disabled application rule checking (all of them usefull for us to modify the validation workflow). And Table Objects are responsible of all of them (patch
column37: I think a solution could be adding an option to method
column39: then entity would be validated before attempting to check application rules or save if  . As an alternative or in addition to
column40: we could also have a property (and its respective method to handle it) on table objects to determine when validation occurs.  Something like... This would allow as to setup this behavior on a per Table basis. Also default value should be \'build\'
column41: to avoid breaking the API. And finally it would be great to have an explicit method on Table Objects
column42: to validate when we want to."'

column10: b'b" One challenge with this will be that all the validation methods would need to be compatible with pre and post casting representations of the data. While I think the core rules should be fine
column11: I\'m not quite as sure that application rules will always abide by that requirement. Associations could also complicate a method as well. It too would need to know which associations should be recursed into and have validation rules applied to them. Handling the association traversal is one of the reasons validation is done on entity build. I think having a method could be a nice addition to the Table class. Adding more modes and options to could muddle the ORM and make usage even more unclear to new and existing developers."'

column10: b'b" Sorry for closing with a short explanation. The long one is that I\'m confident that the current strategy of having stateless AND stageful validation as 2 separate steps was at the end the right solution. There is plenty documentation in the book for how to use both and how one can leverage the other. Moreover
column11: it is possible to manually call any of those validation steps with arbitrary data. If you have any specific suggesting for improvement
column12: please open another ticket. This one got too long to track what\'s actually going on."'

column10: b"b' For stageful validation you mean the build rules?'"

b'b" Short: Yes. Long: Stateful means that you are comparing the data you want to persist into the store with existing data.E.g. if an email address already exists. If a domain is already registered on the network
column11: etc.Stateless validation never requires to know about the state of store that you want to save the data into. Stuff like email === email_repeat is an example. Edit: I can see a point running both
column12: stateless and stateful validations (rules) prior / independent of actually attempting to persist data.   are method names I could see
column13: if they don\'t exist yet."'

b"b' Yes! When updated filed is not listed in $fieldList
column11: it simply means we want to ignore it. Do you have other opinion?Documentation says:'"

column10: b'b" Every single time we\'ve done this in the past it has blown up in our (the maintainers of CakePHP) faces. I much prefer interfaces and code that does what it is told. If you are manually setting the updated field
column11: that is the value you should get. There are use cases where the updated field should be manually set and having magic that overwrites user input makes those use cases impossible. By following explicit input we allow both use cases to exist and the way each scenario is accommodated is clear and easy to understand."'

column10: b'b" @markstory
column11: I\'m only talking about saving model with $fieldList (third parameter of save method) provided. I mean when updated is not listed in $fieldList (so it is not expected to be passed in $data) simply ignore its value (as it is done now) but also fill it with the magic value (instead of removing it totally which is done now). Currently if $data has not updated field and it is not listed in $fieldList
column12: cakephp adds this updated automagically.And when it is expected to set and save updated field as input $data and also $fieldList is provided
column13: simply add updated field to $fieldList."'

column10: b'b" If you are using a then only the fields you whitelist should be saved. No magic. FieldList is a security related option

b"b' @mohsen-ekhtiari Why are you not using SecurityComponent?  Apart from this issue there can be other problems if you only rely on  . E.g. Form can be tampered to remove a field or modify value of hidden field. Just using is not going to prevent either of those.'"
b'b" @ADmad I do use SecurityComponent for some users actions (even using CAPCHA is some). But I do not use it for administrative actions which are mostly bulk AJAX post operations. Furthermore
column11: I do not use it for mobile app submitting post requests.Tampering a form to remove a field is not a concern for me. If the field value is required and could not be calculated
column12: the whole request is invalid and throws error.Changing hidden fields like id are also checked or validated. for example if a user is not allowed to edit an article with some id
column13: is prevented to do so by checking some logic such as being the owner. And if  is allowed to do so
column14: can do it any way
column15: as long as not trying to change not-allowed fields like publish_status.Although CRF is a concern in this way
column16: but logging important changes of database
column17: prevents a possible calamity. So I do not want someone sending a post request with injected updated field and this action although not destructive causes me to lose track of database records\' update time."'

column10: b"b' That means you do need SecurityComponent.'"

Do you you of how to implement their POST or PUT actions?'"

column10: b'b\' @markstory In fact I came to this behavior by an accidental test! I was testing the $fieldList feature to see how it works. And by chance I thought what if someone add an updated field to the form (which all my models have). I expected the newly added updated field by tampering the form (or originally a POST) does not have effect on current behavior of the action because it was banned by $fieldList array. Although I could and did simply add lines to unset updated and created fields from the request data before saving (not lying on $fieldList array for these two fields) to get the updated field changing with current timestamp
column11: I think it is not intuitive (I found it by chance). And If no actions are to be taken and this should be accepted
column12: I recommend following lines to be added to $fieldList behavior for others:"Although $fieldList could be used to prevents user from changing updated and created fields
column13: you should remove these fields manually in order to make automatic updating of these fields working".\''

column10: b"b' @markstory If the value is provided
column11: and allowed in fieldList
column12: the value should be usedIf the value is not provided
column13: the automatic timestamp should be used
column14: regardless of the fieldListIf the value is provided and is blocked by fieldList
column15: the automatic timestamp should be used. The user is preventing malicious users from manually passing the timestamp
column16: but is definitely not opting out of the feature.'"

column10: b"b' I did some digging on this
column11: and because the alias name does not match the association alias
column12: the data is not mapped into an entity. Instead it is left as an array. This is why the hidden field settings are not applied. The root cause of this issue is that associations are stored in a case-insenstive way. This was done to catch duplicate association definitions more easily. I think ensuring that the contained associations use their correct aliases might be a way to prevent this issue.'"

column10: b'b" @janriokrause OK. And I know the reason now. As @lorenzo mentioned above
column11: you cannot call in the if you want to use  . In 2.x
column12: probably as you know
column13: is implemented by a tricky way
column14: by changing associated models and levels temporally on  reading records. And nesting call breaks such a temporary change. (  calls internally.) Concretely
column15: unbinds from

column10: b"b' Your entity
