column13: the following test case passes: Are there any other validation rules on the end_date? '"

column10: b'b" Not that I\'m aware of
column11: the validation rules I pasted in are the only ones that should have any effect. "'

column10: b'b" Ok. I\'ll try reproducing the issue in the context of an application as the data you\'ve provided is considered \'valid\' as far as a unit test is concerned."'
b"b' I tried setting up something similar in a local testing application and the end_time field was marshalled correctly. Also in your original code sample the field has a similiar input definition
column11: and validation rule however that input was marshalled correctly. Given that you have one working field with a 12 hour format
column12: I recommend you figure out what is different between start_time and end_time and go from there.'"

column10: b'b" I\'m not sure why you weren\'t able to reproduce the issue
column11: but I\'ve reproduced it myself using a barebones  fresh project. I\'ve included instructions below to reproduce the issue
column12: as well as the results of my investigation of the bug: # Steps to reproduce ## 1. Create database we\'ll use in our CakePHP project using script below: ## 2. Use composer to create the CakePHP project Command is: php  create-project prefer-dist  [app_name] ## 3. Bake all files necessary to have a basic CRUD application Command is:  bake all time_sheets ## 4. Insert proper DB credentials in [app_name]/  ## 5. Change  view input fields to 12 hour format. Something like this: ## 6. Navigate a browser to [yourprojecturl]/time_ ## 7. Populate start and end time fields with todays date
column13: and 12:10pm and 12:50pm
column14: respectively. Populate other fields however you like. ## 8. Click submit
column15: and observe that the times are both marked as invalid. # My investigation results So I spent some time debugging and have discovered the source of the bug
column16: which seems to be in CakePHP core (specifically
column17: ).  The reason your test case passes is because the values in the data array containing time information are stored as strings
column18: and not ints. See this screenshot: ![screenshot from 2015-09-24 16 32 54]url  And due to the way the validation check works in
column19: arrays of ints will pass where arrays of strings will not. See for yourself with the tests below
column20: the first will pass and the latter will fail: I\'ve narrowed the problem down to a strange bit of code in  (around line 1184 in the version I cloned using the reproduction instructions above
column21: the function in question is \'_getDateString()\') that will convert a string type hour equalling 12 to 24
column22: which is then marked as an invalid time by a regular expression comparison farther down the line in the validation process. I did all this using xdebug
column23: which was very handy.  I tried fixing the bug myself
column24: but ended up with more problems than I started with. So hopefully the information I\'ve provided here can be helpful to you guys."'

column12: which creates javascript for the \'confirm\' resp. \'submit\' actions. However I was able to change some parts (\'FormHelper::postLink\' and DebugKit variables) to support CSP. But I don\'t think I can find all places where changes have to be done. And these changes brings some naming conventions and js file(s) for data attributes resp. to separate the inline javascript code. And also for inline styles. Surely I can  my changes if it is wanted.I hope this request wasn\'t done yet
column13: I didn\'t find anything about CSP in the release infos for 3.1 and also no issue requesting this here. Kind regards"'

column10: b"b' Proposal: new built-in Exception (503 Service Unavailable)'"
b"b' Hi
column11: Scanning through the list of built-in Exceptions on CakePHP 3
column12: I missed the 503 Service Unavailable option. Is there a reason for just error 500 & 501 being implemented at 500-level?'"

column10: b"b' The framework itself has no use case for throwing an exception with 503 status which is why there is no specific exception class for it in the core. There is nothing preventing you from creating a custom exception class in your app with the status code and message you need.'"
b"b' Allright. Thanks @ADmad.'"
b'b" I\'ve come across this issue many times
column11: with different http status codes not implemented. IMO
column12: the Framework should support every HTTP Status Code currently defined at url  given the list isn\'t particularly big
column13: and having them centralized would
column14: I imagine help out a lot of developers who go through the same issue. Happy to do the work and make a PR if it\'s likely to be accepted? /cc @ADmad "'

column10: b"b' Every [HTTP status code]url  is already supported and you can use [Response::statusCode()]url  to set the one you need.'"
b"b' Every status code seems a bit heavy. Would it be acceptable to have generic exception classes for 50x and 4xx errors? Or pehaps factory methods like ?'"
b"b' Perhaps every status code is too heavy
column11: but I have at one project which heavily reliant on status codes. The Network\\\\ contains every status code in an array already
column12: so perhaps a factory method could use that as a source so throw new HttpException(503); Looks up the array in Network\\\\ and throws the already defined message'"

column10: b'b" @alexmcroberts that\'s what I was thinking about when opened this issue. If we already have all the status codes on Response::statusCode() then the HttpException just have to relay this information."'
b"b' Could a reasonable interface also be: This new method would throw an exception halting the request.'"
b"b' I would go with where the message is optional.'"
b"b' @ravage84 Seems reasonable to me.'"
b"b' Can this be closed now since and other exceptions have been added in #7934?'"
b'b" I\'d not include more explicit error codes (e.g. all) just because

column11: and some other frameworks do like this.  Namespace is beter with low nested level but with lot of controller per level. Name is better for deep level with few controller.  The point is not to check if uplevel resources exist but to not combine different logic (i\'ve edited my first message). A comment in article context is not a comment in another context. And sometimes a resource do exist only in a specific context. The combinaison will always be a problem in this classic routing we have
column12: we need to change too much thing to avoid that.  The actual ->resource is not the best always the best thing to do. And we need to put too much different and complex logic inside the controller or inside  the end we don\'t know what context the controller handle

column10: b'b" I don\'t _really_ understand your complain maybe a code snippet would help. The last time I did nested resources was in Rails3 though.url  The basic thoughts I have on your issue are:Only one resource category should be handled by one controller.There should be no chaining of the controllers. The resource logic is being build up by the routes. That\'s where the URLs structure for HTTP calls is being defined.I can see that you might want to have a trait or something for controllers that automatically traverses up and checks stuff... Doing it that way however (instead of having similar logic in your model layer) will create multiple checking queries (instead of inner joins).It is true that your models would inherit the REST compatible nesting of resources (e.g. of ) build up as a tree. Again if that\'s the problem maybe then there should be methods that make it more easy out of the box."'
b'b" The commit in question will not be reverted. It prevents a security vulnerability
column11: which allows any resolvable class to be used as a controller. That exposes a risk around objects with side-effects in their constructors. I\'m sorry you find nested resource routes useless. It sounds like your use-cases are more complex and may require specialized abstractions. The simple nested resources work pretty well for scenarios similar to those described in the article @ionas linked to. Closing as this seems like a question
column12: and the requested revert will not happen."'

column12: but that solve a lot of problem... Sorry if I was unclear. I\'ll try to explain why it is a good idea to route to namespace for rest ressources. First it\'s useless for simple application like in the example.... It\'s a fact that Rest and a traditional MC model is not the best way to handle this use cases. It\'s difficult to make combinaison of contexts
column13: ... Given these facts we need to enhance this functionnality because we can\'t easily create context without namespaces. And it\'s not my invention take a look how this project is organised url  Before cake 3 we didn\'t have namespace
column14: so some of us use plugin to easily create context. But now it\'s possible so we need to use it. Why the prefix option routes to a different namespace ? because a controller inside a prefix context is not a controller inside another context... **One example** We have an user
column15: UsersController can easily handle the  context and the defaut context (when we get this user). We do it without thinking about it
column16: nothing strange here. Now we have a profile
column17: adress
column18: and so many controllers that ONLY exist in the user context. So we need an Users namespace. Now we have :UsersControllerUsers\\\\ProfilesControllerUsers\\\\AdressesController The response to this : it\'s useless. Yes **it\'s useless if we think like in classic cakephp MVC app**. Users controller deserialize the whole thing and the model save the associations
column19: we maybe only need one controller etc... So now think Rest. Ok
column20: we use the actual thing ->resource . We create all the controllers in the same namespace and in each we check if we are inside the user context
column21: since the resource only exist in this context. Now
column22: I want a common logic to all controllers in user context (and no
column23: trait is not a good choice I think)
column24: I want to easily beforeFilter for this context
column25: I want to multiply the number of these cotnroller by 10 without probelm. I understand nothing to ruby but what I understand is that the gitlab example seems like what I want to do (and what I already do in large app). So my solution is :Add support for classic namespace routing with ->connectAdd support for Controller name option for rest nestedAdd support for rest nested namespace routing With these three things we cover a lot of situations. Thank you"'

b'b" Perhaps I am misunderstanding how cache engines are supposed to work. So let me start there. I have a cache config created called \'short\'
column11: it uses the Redis engine and there are no groups defined in the config. I create a bunch of Cache entries as such: I run
column12: and I would expect it to do something roughly equivalent to this command:
column13: only in PHP code. However
column14: I go to inspect the source code for RedisEngine::clearGroup
column15: and it finds a key called \'foo_bar\'
column16: and increments its value. It does nothing else. I issue a command and I see not only the keys I created via but the new foo_bar key. Is there some redis concept or group concept that I am missing here? The docs make clearGroup sound like it\'s for deleting a bunch of grouped keys
column17: but the implementation here doesn\'t seem to match that. "'

column10: b"b' It seems to me the body for clearGroup should actually be:  '"
b'b" What you\'ve described is not how groups work. You can only clear groups if you have groups configured. Using is not something I would be comfortable in adding either."'
b'b" Ok
column11: can you explain a bit more on how the groups are meant to work then? Because I read through the entire RedisEngine file and the only other mention of group is in the function \'groups\'. There is nothing else that reads
column12: writes
column13: or deletes based on the group in the file. And even if we\'re pre-defining groups
column14: I don\'t see how the current body of clearGroup actually does what it advertises
column15: which is delete a bunch of keys that are in the given group. The current body of clearGroup is:  "'

column10: b'b" Also
column11: according to the docs here: url  It makes it sound as though the \'groups\' setting is more about applying groups to an entire Cache config
column12: not for declaring which groups the cache entries are allowed to exist in. In the example
column13: it says: So how do I configure a new group without applying it to every key entered through that config?"'

column10: b'b" You don\'t. Groups are intended to make clearing data _across_ multiple configurations easier. For example if you have multiple cache durations you can use groups to clear keys in both configurations without needing to know the configuration names ahead of time. For example a cache with a 1 min duration
column11: and a cache with a 5 day duration
column12: can share a group
column13: which can then be \'invalidated\' with one call to clearGroup(). The incrementer doesn\'t \'clear\' data but increments the generational key which allows  to garbage  the keys on their own. This avoids costly and dangerous operations like in redis."'

column10: b'b" Got it. I still don\'t quite get the last bit
column11: and it doesn\'t appear to actually work for me (I apply a group of \'foo\' to my config \'short\'
column12: I save a key with config \'short\'
column13: then I call clearGroup(\'foo\') and go to read the key again and it\'s still there)
column14: but I assume I just don\'t understand the system well enough to see why the key isn\'t invalidating when I call Cache::clearGroup"'

column10: b"b' Cake relies on redis for evicting the keys from memory. What clearGroup() guarantees is that the following reads will not return that value.'"

b'b" No
column11: this is bad. should not be treated as a key value for an index. This leads to other issues such as using null as a primary key
column12: or what position null has in an ordered list. I think at the data storage level this is a problem. MySQL for example does not support null for unique indexes. It just ignores it. If a column allows null and has a unique index it can contain many nulls. You don\'t gain any index performance by using null either. What ever problem it was that you were originally trying to solve. There was probably was a better way to solve it than testing for unique null."'

column10: b'b\' As the one suggesting that possible "solution" for the given "problem"
column11: without putting the root of the problem to question
column12: and possibly offering solutions that don\\\'t require such controversial constraints
column13: let me add my tree fiddy... AFAIR
column14: MySQLs BDB engine supported as a unique value
column15: however that engine is gone since 5.1
column16: so it\\\'s not relevant for CakePHP anymore. SQL Server on the other hand supports it (it always did if I\\\'m not mistaken
column17: and you have to use filters to change this behavior)
column18: which some people like
column19: and some don\\\'t
column20: as it contradicts the ANSI standard. With respect to that historical behavior
column21: being able to represent this in the form of an application rule might come handy for some SQL Server peeps
column22: whether this justifies core feature relevance however is of debatable nature. Rethinking it
column23: I think I\\\'d now possibly tend more towards
column24: nah
column25: might not be an overly good idea
column26: enforcing standards on that level of the abstraction layer might be better. Making the rule more extensible may be a compromise
column27: so that people could easily modify the conditions without having to reimplement the whole rules logic.\''

column10: b'b" @StageCoachDriver the issue described here and in the Chronos issue is due  to a PHP memory corruption bug.  As a _side effect_ of the memory corruption the Class errors shown above occur.  But the Class is not structured incorrectly
column11: it\'s just getting clobbered by the PHP memory corruption bug.  If you are hitting this bug it will only occur occasionally.  Most of the time your class will work just fine
column12: but 1 in a 100 (or 1000
column13: or whatever) the memory corruption will clobber the Class and things fall apart.  Then you may see the errors described above.  If you are seeing the bug on _every_ page load then you have a different problem.  If you are sure you are seeing the issue described here you can confirm it easily by running your code with either PHP 5.6 or 7.2 (beta). This bug never occurs with those two versions of PHP."'

column10: b"b' And it is worth pointing out for others that this Issue and the linked Chronos issue are _not_ bugs in the framework.  They are PHP bugs.  The Chronos issue is being left open so that it is visible to the community
column11: not because it is awaiting a fix in the Framework.'"

b'b" This is a (multiple allowed):[x] bug[x] enhancement[ ] feature-discussion (RFC)CakePHP Version: 3.2.9
column11: specifically 02c8f32Platform and Target: Ubuntu 16.04
column12: CLI
column14: MySQL 5.7.12### What you did Let\'s say I have two models (Posts belongsTo Users)
column15: and let\'s say that I want some Posts to be unowned (meaning the  column can be null). So my SQL to create the Posts table looks like this: As you can see
column16: I have a unique index that makes sure no two posts that are owned by the same user share the same title. So in PostsTable::validationDefault() I put this:  ### Expected Behavior Two unowned Posts can have the same title. The unique index on my SQL table allows this. This worked up through 3.2.8.### Actual Behavior In 3.2.9
column17: the validation fails when two unowned Posts share the same title. Reverting 02c8f32 restores the old behavior. I guess this was the intention of the commit
column18: but it breaks backward compatibility
column19: and it will confuse people who expect Cake to handle the uniqueness of null values the same way that the underlying SQL indexes do (as was the case prior to 3.2.9). Perhaps it would be better to add an option to activate the new behavior if desired
column20: but still default to the old (at least until version 3.3)? I\'m sure lots of other people\'s apps also rely on the old
column21: SQL-style  behavior
column22: and I think it would be preferable to not have to switch to custom providers and manually write new validation methods just to get them working again with 3.2.9+."'

column10: b'b" Currently allowEmpty() is a \'state\' on a field. When set to true
column11: empty values are allowed and no validators are run. Instead we could move to a model where appends a new rule that adds a validation error if the field contains an empty value. would effectively be a no-op and other validation methods on the field would run as normal.  I wouldn\'t overload the current methods as this would be a breaking change in my opinion. But we could add new methods that add this behavior and deprecate the existing allow empty behavior."'

column11: PHP 7.0### What you did Keep running into cases where CakePHP is not handling PHP 7\\\'s new "Error" and "Throwable" exceptions.### Expected Behavior Cells trigger a server 500 if there is a thrown during render.Transactions not commit and leak if there is an class thrown.Basically
column12: anywhere there is a the code does not work as expected in PHP 7.### Actual Behavior PHP 7 introduced a new error type
column13: and gave and a common interface  . All methods that do a broad catch all should be doing in PHP 7. I don\\\'t know how to address this issue in a backward compatible way. Maybe use a global function that wraps a closure in the proper  type for the current PHP version? As this been discussed anywhere else by the Cake team?\''

column10: b'b" Would something like this work without issues in PHP 5.x? I found this while googling
column11: but wouldn\'t Throwable be a undeclared type in PHP 5?  "'

b'b" PHP is funny in that it won\'t complain about missing classes used in  blocks. It will however try to autoload them. Instead of duplicating all the blocks
column11: could we conditionally define  ? Something like: That should enable us to use throughout CakePHP in a transparent to PHP7 way."'

column10: b'b" It\'s an interface
column11: but still. I think you\'re onto something. I might close this and try again."'

column10: b'b" I was thinking some more
column11: and my suggestion won\'t work as isn\'t using :cry:."'

column10: b'b\' I thinking of a closure fix. This won\\\'t work where there are multiple catches for known exceptions plus
column11: but I think there is only 1 or 2 places like that. Also
column12: the above only applies to  that are for any error. Maybe we need to revisit that code and review if such a broad catch is really needed. Another point is that you can use "find usages" in an IDE and quickly see where this is being done.\''

column10: b"b' 500 errors are a good thing! How would you otherwise know that you have a syntax error
column11: an uncommitted file
column12: a type mismatch
column13: etc? If we catch the errors and deprive the users from things as basic as a stacktrace and some log output
column14: those errors may go unnoticed and left unfixed. This would be the equivalent of PHP 5.2 notices and using silencing the error output to make the problem go away. There may be
column15: though
column16: cases where it is a good idea to catch the error
column17: but I would like to take them case by base.'"

column10: b'b" I am not in favor of the closure approach. Almost all exceptions shouldn\'t occur in normal case. Creating two closures and calling user defined functions everytime everywhere is not a good idea.  Can\'t we catch Throwable after catching Exception?  Never mind. I forgot about [how instanceof triggers autoloader in PHP]url "'

column11: but adding throwable to the group of catch all might not be a good idea.'"

column11: but I could not. For some stupid reason

column13: don\\\'t fix it" applies.\''

column10: b'b" @dereuromark just to add. I\'ve had a lot of experience since this post with PHP 7
column11: and I\'m under the impression that a developer should not be catching the new Throwable interface. Only Exceptions
column12: as catching these fatal PHP errors is a major change in behavior from PHP 5.6 I\'ve since changed my project to allow the type to be uncaught
column13: and as a result closing the transaction is no longer an issue since the app is going to crash anyway
column14: and the DB connection should be closed (which is an auto rollback)."'

column10: b"b' Closing then'"
b'b\' It looks like we need this for at least the error handler and some low level logging etc
column11: otherwise php7 errors (Throwable) happening in those will not be properly handled.  It should in those cases always look like this:    try {     ...   } catch (Throwable $exception) {     ...   } catch (Exception $exception) {     ...   }  In case of PHP5.6 those will just be ignored and the fallback will be used. We do not need to add this for high level exceptions where it is clear only "old" kind of exceptions are expected.\''

column10: b"b' I think Exceptions should be caught earlier than Throwable
column11: as we might want to rethrow Errors to keep existing behavior except bugs. So we might write different code in the two blocks. (I left a similar comment above. Though I struck out my comment
column12: from a different view point
column13: now I think my suggestion itself is not wrong)'"

column13: I\'m going to close this."'

column10: b"b' RFC Make Cake\\\\Network\\\\Request implement PSR7 ServerRequestInterface'"
b'b" This is a (multiple allowed):[ ] bug[x] enhancement[x] feature-discussion (RFC) In 3.3
column11: we added a PSR7 \'bridge\' component. For 3.4
column12: I\'m proposing that implement the PSR7  . This provides a few benefits:Consistency across the framework. Both middleware and  will have access to the PSR7 interface methods.More immutable objects. Immutable objects have some nice benefits and having more of them feels like a good thing.Less duplication. Currently our request object
column13: and the PSR7 transformers duplicate a significant amount of code with diactoros. By adopting the PSR7 features in we would be able to remove a large chunk of duplicate code. I also feel that the PSR7 interfaces help promote consistency across different PHP frameworks
column14: which is beneficial to new users who have used other PHP frameworks. We of course will continue to offer additional \'sugar\' methods that make using the PSR7 objects more ergonomic. For example setting cache headers will continue to have higher level methods
column15: as the PSR7 interfaces are too low-level.## Dealing with Mixed Mode Operations in Requests Currently our request objects are mutable
column16: while PSR7 requests are _immutable_. Bridging this gap will seamlessly is not be feasible. Instead
column17: I\'m proposing we take the same approach we took with
column18: and continue to honor in-place mutation for the existing methods
column19: while offering new immutable interfaces.## Combined  The methods that act as both a setter & getter would be deprecated. New getters would be added that follow the PSR7 conventions more closely. For example and  . We would introduce new methods for the setter mode in the conventional PSR7 style: New setters would be introduced:  ## Deprecate ArrayAccess methods The ArrayAccess interface was added in 2.x to provide an easier upgrade path from 1.x. This interface would be deprecated in 3.4. It is not possible to support ArrayAccess and immutable objects long term. Long term
column20: this would remove calls like:  ## Deprecate magic methods The current magic methods
column21: would be deprecated. These interfaces are infrequently used
column22: and become harder to support in an immutable context. This would break access like:  ## Deprecate public properties The existing public properties
column27: and would be deprecated. Instead data should be read through  public methods: The
column28: and parameters would be replaced with the existing sugar methods: The current public URI properties would be available as request \'attributes\'
column29: or be exposed through new methods that match the PSR7 conventions: Because attributes and the existing public properties do not share the same storage
column31: and to emulate the properties using the PSR7 storage. Most of the emulated properties are scalar values which is great
column32: as they are simple to emulate. However
column35: and emulating arrays with and can have some limitations. I think this is a situation where we would need documentation in the migration guide to explain the limitations.# Impact to Existing Components Several core components would be effected by the switch to immutable request objects
column36: and would need to be rebuilt. While these updates are not critical for 3.4.0 as we\'ll continue to support the in-place mutation methods
column37: long term we need to replace the effected components with middleware based solutions
column38: and I think it is important to have plans now on how those updates will be done. I am not recommending these changes be done in 3.4.0. In order to keep releases smaller
column39: component to middleware changes could be done in 3.5.0.## Convert CsrfComponent to Middleware This component could be replaced entirely by a middleware layer. The component could be deprecated entirely
column40: we could recommend people update to the new Middleware layer.## RequestHandlerComponent Input Parsing The input parsing feature of would need to be moved into middleware. The other features of RequestHandlerComponent could stay in the component.### beforeRedirect conversion into requestAction This feature should be deprecated and planned for removal in 4.x. This feature was missed in the 2.x deprecations and should be removed now.## Convert SecurityComponent to Middleware SecurityComponent token validation could be converted into Middleware as well. The and features could be moved into a separate middleware allowing each layer to be more focused on solving specific problems. The underlying token validation and token generation should be moved into a utility class that can be re-used in both the component and middleware layer.# Unimpacted Core ComponentsAuthComponent No impact as auth manipulates the session which is not-immutable.FlashComponent Uses Session data exclusively.CookieComponent Uses Cookies which go into the Response (which is a separate harder problem).## TODO[x] Implement PSR7 interface on request.  [x] Attribute methods  [x] Query string methods  [x] Server parameter methods  [x] Cookie methods  [x] HTTP method methods  [x] Parsed Body methods  [x] Uploaded Files methods  [x] Body stream methods  [x] Request target methods  [x] Protocol Version methods  [x] Header methods  [x] Implement interface  [x] Uri methods[x] Make ServerRequestFactory return a Network\\\\Request instance.[x] Deprecate and remove usage of RequestTransformer. Instead pass through the middleware and controller.[x] Create to be an alias for  .[x] Update core code to use PSR7 methods where possible.[x] Update Validation methods that deal with files to work with  .[x] Update documentation to include pre + post 3.4 examples.[x] Add new getter methods that more closely follow PSR7 conventions.## ChangelogRemoved added method. The current query() method does not allow modifying the query parameters.Added deprecations of getter mode in mixed mode  methods."'

column10: b'b" I don\'t think the current code is incorrect. In components of components will be lazily constructed
column11: and components of components _should not_ be attached to event listeners. Is there a reason you can\'t append to the required Controller?"'

column10: b'b" And they are not attached by default. But when one explicitly uses anyone would expect callbacks to be enabled.There is no reason why it can\'t be done. But when a component is used in multiple controllers then that extra sub-component would need to be appended to each controller."'
b"b' Fair point.'"
b"b' I noticed that this feature introduces a new configuration option to components. For Is there a better way to handle this?'"

column11: right? Now it only respects custom option values.'"

column10: b'b" I don\'t think the component\'s configuration should even be touched. We should deprecate the option when lazy loading
column11: and developers that want to have event listeners on inner components should load them manually with the flag turned on via the ComponentRegistry."'

b"b' Issue 7324 paginator sort multiple fields'"

b"b' This resolves issue #7324 as described in my comment there.  You can define the sort order of pagination in pagination settings array. These settings are unioned with the request query parameters
column11: request query always comes first.  Due to the union
column12: if the sort field of the request query is already defined by the settings array
column13: the settings array will not overwrite the request query sort field.  If no request query sort field is set (e.g. initial page 1)
column14: the pagination URL is created with the first settings entry
column15: which has the same effect than ommiting it in the URL. '"

column10: b'b" @mirko-pagliai response has no getType() method on purpose. Instead you can use getHeaderLine() to access the content-type header.  Why wouldn\'t be used to read properties on immutable objects?  That is a pattern we already use quite a bit. Having two conventions for property reading methods makes remembering how to use objects harder than if we had one convention for all methods.  Having two conventions for setter methods on  objects makes sense as the name of the method lets you know how the object behaves."'

b'b" @mirko-pagliai your failed test is consistent with that I\'m seeing here as well.  So what is happening is that buffered queries are using SplFixedArray
column11: and that object is being serialized when written to the cache. When the ResultSet is restored from the cache PHP is failing to properly restore the inner state of SplFixedArray. The ResultSet successfully loads the items in the cache
column12: but the count for items is set to zero. The data is there but it will fail trying to iterate any of the items.  I\'ve updated the PR this morning to improve serializing. It no longer uses SplFixedArray when writing to the cache
column13: but converts the result set to a regular array. When the result set is deserialized from cache it\'s converted back into a new SplFixedArray instance with a proper count value.  Based upon what I\'ve read in your post. The PR should fix your issue.  I do not know why this bug started to appear
column14: but I\'ve been on slack today talking @lorenzo who also experienced this issue on  a different version of PHP. The code that introduced this issue was added to Cake a year ago
column15: but this issue seems to have just started recently.  Spl is a core component of PHP since 5.3. What I think might have happen is that some thing in Cake recently changed in one of the iterator traits we use
column16: and that introduced the bug so that would not work.  Anyway
column17: the bug is fixed now. It\'ll be in the next Cake update."'

column16: very strange. I personally found that the bug has also appeared on CakePHP installation outdated and that worked until a few days ago. Really strange.'"

column11: We were also experiencing this on our live environment
column12: so first I would like thank you for your hard work on this issue!  In the meatime I also  started looking into it
column13: and found a way to reproduce it in a contained example. What I found is that returned 0 when used in the unserialize function directly. Outside of the class however
column14: after the full is unserialized
column15: would return the correct amount. So there is some code being executed right after the complete object is unserialized (php internals that is probably).  Now I found this: [SplFixedArray::__wakeup]url The suggested to me it would be private
column16: but apparently it is not and can be called in the function right after SplFixedArray is unserialized and stored in  .  Therefore I added right after the following [line of code]url This solved the problem for me. I know it is quite late after all the work that has already been done. But thought I\'d share it anyway. Hopefully it helps in some way. Cheers! "'

b"b' [RFC] Association name setter'"
b'b" Following [comments]url Association names are mutable
column11: but that change isn\'t reflected in a collection nor the target table. Changing association name without manually reattaching it in a collection makes it unusable. [checks if these names match]url  and throws an exception. Is this exception enough or should we disallow changing association name as it would probably break it?  In other words key
column12: name and target alias should be identical. Changing one of them would probably break things.  My way to improve this is to check if a new association name matches the target table alias **after** it has been resolved.  There\'s also an issue with not reflecting association name change
column13: but I\'m not sure we can do anything about it without changing the way associations are collected."'

b"b' 3.next Consolidate CookieCollections'"

b'b" This is a (multiple allowed):  * [ ] bug * [ ] enhancement * [x] feature-discussion (RFC)  CakePHP 3.5.0 will feature a new set of cookie objects that provide an object-orienated interface to building and using HTTP cookies. As of #10328 we have a few different Cookie \'collections\'. I\'d like to unify those collections with the goal of only having 1 single cookie collection
column11: as I don\'t think the use-cases we have require 4 classes.  ### Use Cases for a CookieCollection  CookieCollections are used in a few different places in CakePHP:  1. In an Http\\\\Client as a cookie jar where state is retained between client requests. 2. Adding cookies to a Controller Response. 3. Reading cookie data from a ServerRequest.  Each use case requires some common methods and some use-case specific methods.  ### Generic Methods  * Iteration (IteratorAggregate) * Check if a cookie exists * Get a cookie * Remove a cookie * Add a cookie  ### Methods specific to Http\\\\Client usage  This is the most complex use-case to afford as there are backwards compatibility concerns. The new methods & backwards compatibility behavior required are:  * Add cookies from a response. A request is needed to infer the path and domain of cookies that have not included it. Currently this method is called  . This  would be deprecated. * Apply all the cookies matching this request. Currently calls this method  . This behavior for would be deprecated and could be shimmed by looking for cookie \'names\' that contain the URL sub-pattern. Cookies names containing are very rare
column12: and we can use this as a sniff to enable backwards compatible behavior case libraries that consume  .  These methods allow a CookieCollection to function as a \'cookie jar\' for the client. Covering another use case currently covered by a standalone class. ### Methods specific to adding cookies to a Controller Response  * Add cookies in the collection to a response.  ### Methods specific to Reading cookie data from a ServerRequest  * Build a new CookieCollection from a request object.  All of the above methods could be implemented in a single class allowing us to streamline how users have to interact with cookies in CakePHP even further.  ### Edits  * Removed  . I don\'t have any use cases for it. "'

column10: b"b' Regarding Http\\\\Client use cases: this would mutate current collection? this would return a new request with modified headers?'"
b"b'  also url '"

b'b\'  I\\\'m OK with but but the only solution I could think of right now is a singleton which has it\\\'s downsides as well. A "service" like object attached to the request as attribute might work as well but then you don\\\'t have access to the response either.  For what you want to do I think the best thing would be a new cookie component
column11: because the controller layer is probably for cookies the most likely place to be read and written by a framework user. So we could attach the related collection as attribute to request and response
column12: this would make them virtually everywhere available and have the component for a streamlined convenient access in the controller layer.\''

column10: b'b" @robertpustulka Yes to both questions. CookieCollections currently and in the future would be mutable (unlike proper objects). I felt this was acceptable as they also lack all the methods of standard collections as well. I\'m open to not using \'collection\' if you think people will be confused."'

b'b"  I was thinking that the new cookie collection could be exposed by methods on both the request and response providing a reasonable way to integrate the new cookie objects into the .  I\'m less interested in the component use cases
column11: and more interested in consolidating the code we have in both the cookie collections in and making the core  objects more useful. Having object based cookies that are only used in a component seems like a missed opportunity."'

column10: b'b" I\'ll try and reproduce again. I was able to reproduce & fix what must have a been a similar issue then. Attaching eager loaded associations in a beforeFind() like this is dangerous
column11: as the beforeFind() will be called twice for the count() query.  You might want to consider using a named finder instead of a beforeFind(). "'

column10: b'b" I\'m not sure this issue can be fixed. In my previous fix
column11: I had the order of count()/all() flipped. This exposed a different issue that shares a root cause with this one. When a query is executed multiple times
column12: state in the is shared between executions. The
column13: ordering was simpler to fix as when a copy is made for the count operation
column14: I was able to deep clone the EagerLoader breaking the state being linked.  In this scenario
column15: is called first
column16: and the is modified as part of the execution
column17: then when is called
column18: it re-uses the already populated
column19: reapplying the operations. This re-application combined with how multiple calls to with the same key \'merge\' the loader functions causes the issue. On the second run
column20: the loader is defined
column21: and is decorated as the key matches an existing loader. The redefinition of a loader results in the conditions being applied to the dummy query that was defined in the execution.  I\'ll try and see if PaginatorComponent can clone the queries before executing them
column22: but in the mean time you should avoid nested matching() calls and prefer to use the dot paths for deep associations:   The above should generate the results you\'re looking for without the SQL errors. "'

column10: b'b" The message parsed on L115 *is* singular as it is a *single* message without plural forms attached. The parser can\'t look at the contents of message ids to guess whether they are singular or plural values."'
b"b' RFC: Router scope cache'"
b'b" This is a (multiple allowed):  * [] bug * [x] enhancement * [x] feature-discussion (RFC)  * CakePHP Version: 3.next * Platform and Target: 3.next  In projects where several routes are connected
column11: sometimes with routes coming from the database or external files
column12: there is a possible optimization caching the generated RouteCollection.  ### Interface  The interface for this cache could be located in the scope params and define the scoped route like  Router::scope(\'/\'
column13: [\'_cache\' = The param defines the cache configuration to use
column14: and the cache key will be the of the scope.  ### Test config and results  This is the configuration I\'ve used for testing performance locally (using default File based cache)   **Times  cache were:  0.00463 vs 0.00276 for 50 connected routes 1.45s vs 0.015 for 4000 connected routes**  ### Implementation notes:  * We could think of another implementation Router::cache() to define global caching of the RouteCollection (it\'s static anyway) but I think it\'s better to let the user define which scopes should be cached. * If 2 or more scopes are cached
column15: the per scope cache will store previous cached router collection twice as the RouteCollection object is static
column16: this could be a possible improvement in a future PR if this one is looking good. * This feature is BC with existing 3.x versions  ### Todo:  * Add new option to documentation * Add note about using to build the routes cache as a deploy step   "'

column10: b'b" Sounds like a good idea to me. Would this cache be clearable using a shell?  I guess it\'d also respect the configured configuration flag?"'
b"b' Closing as there is a pull request open now.'"
b'b" Here\'s another round on the route-caching topic. I\'ve been testing the middleware based routing cache and this would remove some of the issues with the scope based caching
column11: getting all the routeCollection serialized and reused between requests. The new CacheRoutingMiddleware class would look like this:  We would need to add a Router::setRouteCollection setter.  There could be specific use cases where the cache would not work
column12: like connecting routes based on dynamic conditions. If we want to cover this use case
column13: we could think about 2 methods in
column14: one for cached routes
column15: another for non-cached and we would need to ensure we run the non-cached routes on every request.  Please let me know your thoughts
column16: I can get a PR with these changes over the next days.  The new \'router\' cache configuration would be added to skeleton. would be respected
column17: just trying to get details out of the example."'

column10: b"b' @steinkel That looks like a _much_ cleaner and simpler implementation :clap:'"
b'b" Thinking about a new CacheRoutingMiddleware vs using existing RoutingMiddleware and configuration
column11: the second option looks better because we could have an environment based configuration for the route collection caching
column12: working the same as the core and model caches in development mode (2 minutes). I\'ll work on a PR based on these ideas..."'

column10: b'b" @lorenzo readme is updated in this PR as well: url I\'m leaning towards @dereuromark opinion on this. I could remove warnings but keep deprecation annotations.  Another idea is to keep static API as it is but update the core to never use TableRegistry static methods and update docs to show how to use locators instead (this is already done here more or less). This way we could keep the static methods for people that use them (IDEs wouldn\'t mark methods as deprecated) but encourage new people to use locators instead (by never showing that something like exists). b'b" I\'ve ran into a similar issue. Turned out that this error was **not** the primary error. Something else was failing much earlier preventing fixtures to be loaded. I realized this by examining the file which showed the first error as well.  I am only posting this because w/o the file it is very unlikely to find the cause of this problem.  It would be interesting if other people stumbling into this can have a look at their files and check. ### Sqlite vs Mysql Driver In my case Sqlite was behaving slightly different than my original Mysql connection. So this error only showed when using the Sqlite driver to run my tests
column11: but not with Mysql."'

column10: b"b' Related to #9931'"
b"b' What is harder about creating an exception handler now compared with 3.3?'"
b'b" As of 3.3
column11: ErrorHandler doesn\'t catch any exceptions usually
column12: as ErrorHandlerMiddleware catches and discards them earlier than ErrorHandler. So the following section of the Cookbook is no longer accurate. url  In addition to create a custom error handler
column13: people have to extend ErrorHandlerMiddleware
column14: or remove ErrorHandlerMiddleware from HTTP middleware stack."'

column10: b"b' The global error handler is still used
column11: but only for errors before the middleware is reached. I can see how the current state is not as elegant as it could be though.'"

column10: b"b' Uncatchable errors
column11: such as E_ERROR
column12: would also be handled by the global error handler via the handleFatalError() method. Anyway
column13: the current error handling process seems more complex than 3.3. So I suggested to make ErrorHandlerMiddleware use ErrorHandler::handleException() instead of its own exception handling code. ErrorHandler::handleException() will come to be called for any type of .'"

column10: b'b" All PHP errors go to the existing ErrorHandler and not the middleware. Using the ErrorHandler inside the middleware presents a couple challenges. 1. The current handleException() method directly outputs whereas the middleware needs to return a response. 2. We don\'t yet have a way to pass an ErrorHandler into the middleware.  These are solvable issues
column11: but they should be figured out."'

b"b' It could. The method signature of the is the following: How do we pass the ErrorHandler to this? There would be several choices using the argument
column11: adding the third argument
column12: or constructor overloading.'"

They are "success" codes. I won\\\'t digg into the RFC now but here the WP article: url  * However... only a few are considered ok: url  * aka: 200
column17: and 226 are OK
column18: too  ### What you expected to happen isOk() to return true for all 2xx codes.  ### What do you suggest  * isOK() should return true for all 2xx codes. If this is not deemed BC compatible: * is2xx() could be implemented which returns true for all 2xx codes

column10: b"b' Refs url To widen the range as per definition via bugfix can be considered BC
column11: only closing it would not be BC. So it is more the issue of what codes are going to be included in isOk(). I agree that all 2xx are usually meant to be that.  Please note that assertResponseOk() of test cases currently also only see 200...204 as OK. The rest is covered in assertResponseSuccess().  So whatever is done should be consistent across both levels. So maybe a isSuccess() similar to IntegrationTestCase could cover what you mean? Or we consolidate them together and both classes in the future only have a single isOk() one
column12: would probably make the most sense. We can deprecate the other one.  This can target 3.6 IMO for the enhancements as specified here.'"

column10: b"b' Personally I am fine if isOk returns true for the 2xx range. But I am not so sure about BC... real world apps just test isOk => return... 208 => do that
column11: 226 => do something else.'"

column10: b'b" Do you frequently use 205-226? While they could fall under \'ok\' I\'ve personally never seen them actually used
column11: and would prefer to keep them out of the common paths until there is a good case to include them. Adding 203 & 204 in #11521 made sense as a number of APIs use 204 for DELETE and PUT responses."'

column10: b'b\' The thing is that I am convinced that it is not up to us to decide but the IETF HTTP working group and that we should follow  as closely as possible to make life easy and with less unexpected  behavior for developers.  Why add exceptions and make stuff harder "by default"?  IMHO: For us the only question is: Is something that is _successful_ by standard _ok_? I think it is.  I can prep the PR to add the full range of 2xx codes in there explicitly or better yet we just test for the first digit
column11: or I can add a method is2xx() that does that and extend the book. Edit: the last PR #11521 was only necessary because of the stance of mind of "do you frequently use xy?" instead of "the standard says xy
column12: and it is easy and straightforward to implement
column13: so we just do it(tm)".\''

column10: b'b\' Long Short: We are neither following HTTP spec nor we are following community practise as of now.  Ref: url  url  ^ both interpret just 200 as "ok" any other success is "not ok".  If we walk that path we should implement it the exact same way those frameworks do (but that will not be BC) and then add is2xx() for convenience and recommend for peeps to use that?\''
b"b' Again: just add isSuccessful() consistent with IntegrationTestCase
column11: nothing else required IMO. OK to be 200-204 is acceptable and for BC reasons not changeable now anyway.'"

column12: PHP 7  ### What you did I\\\'ve got two tables  Events  and  Dates  ( Events  hasMany  Dates ):    I want to insert a **new** Event including a **new** Date. Therefore i created a form:   Patching the data according to this code:  The resulting entity (output of debug) looks correct:  Nevertheless the save fails.  ### What happened The save of the created entity fails due to:  Intern there is a new event id generated. This id is not persistent in the moment of executing the "application build rules" on  Dates . So the rule  existsIn  will fail.  ### What you expected to happen The existsIn rules by the buildRules should be ignored while the parent entity is a new one. OR the existsIn rules should be able to verify the "in memory" existing event id.  I do not want to remove this rules because they are an essential check but they cause an error if you try to save a **new** entity with **new** a nested has many entity. But there is indeed a bug. If I update the  Dates  of an **existing** (already persited)  Event  then it works correct. Because the  ExistsIn  rule can find the referenced id of  Event . column12: you will get the validation error."'

b"b' Email assertions'"
b'b" This is a proposal for #11973. Replaces the with an
column11: added on
column12: that allows devs to make assertions against any emails sent through the test transport. Testing emails only requires replacing the transport class in  :   Now any emails sent through the default transport will be captured for later assertions. Here\'s a list of the new assertions (  param removed for brevity):  These assertions assert against any email was sent during the test case.   : Asserts email was sent to an email address  : Asserts email was sent from an email address  : Asserts email contains contents  : Asserts email contains contents in HTML portion of message  : Asserts email contains contents in text portion of message  : Asserts expectation against other email fields
column13: such as or  The above assertions have a sibling method suffixed with
column14: which can be used if multiple emails are sent during a single test. Provide the argument with the position you expected the email to be sent.   Finally
column15: some count assertions:   : Asserts emails were sent  : Asserts no emails were sent "'

b"b' Sessions: session_write_close() and redirect() data not saved on php-'"
b'b\' This is a (multiple allowed):  * [x] bug * [ ] enhancement * [ ] feature-discussion (RFC)  * CakePHP Version: 3.7.0 * Platform and Target: php-fpm 7.1.26-1+ubuntu16.04.1++1
column11: nginx 1.10.3 * Using database sessions no specials
column12: just plain vanilla. Off in fpm config.  ### What you did We were doing final testing of our app after major upgrade and noticed that some code does not work as it should. The code is highly dependent on session variables as they hold the state. The script updates the state in the session just before redirecting and then we noticed
column13: that the variable that is written before the redirect is not written to the session itself. It does succeed after ca. 8-10 attempts. ### What happened I am not sure how much of a problem it is but it\\\'s not something that is wildly discussed other places. I also have a feeling this could somehow be related to #11162. I can reproduce this behavior on my php-fpm setup every time. I cannot reproduce it when running on cakephp built-in server. The following snippet shows the problem (controller action):  If you access the url as it should print the timestamp recorded at the time of the redirect. But it does not. If you manage to save the timestamp you will notice it is not changing on subsequent requests where is in the URL. Snippet above will work EVERY time if you add the following after and before the statement:   Then it works flawlessly as intended. Session data is written automatically on and if I terminate the script with an before the return then data is also saved correctly in the database. ### What you expected to happen Where does it come from. It "used to work" w/o problems on older PHP  version. I would expect it just worked as intended i.e. when I do I would like to have that data stored in the session.  How is the administered internally by cakephp? Isn\\\'t it an idea to add it into the and check whether session is started etc. and then explicitly close it? Are there better alternatives that could solve this problem for majority of "possible" cases?  \''

column10: b'b" Normally the session_write_close() is handled by the sapi and we don\'t explicitly close the session. You could use to close the session in a way that will it to automatically be reopened as necessary.  In older versions we would always close the session even when it wasn\'t open
column11: but I think that caused some compatibility issues in newer php versions."'

column10: b"b' I had same problem with iteration over ResultSet. My ResultSet also had 30 items inside but foreach iterated only once for the first item. I also used ->toArray() method as a tempotary fix
column11: but i kept digging for the real cause. The cause of the problem in my case was xdebug on PHP7 (it works correctly on PHP5 with xdebug) If you set ini setting with value higher than xdebug on PHP7 starts to mess with internal variables of some Iterable objects and this can cause premature breaking out of the loop after first item. Setting ini setting to fixed the problem for me.  '"

column10: b"b' Thanks
column11: @Asgraf for the insight. You are correct in that it is an xdebug issue. Setting the to had no effect (it was at before) but when I disable listening for the debugger
column12: I have no issues at all and the script executes as expected.'"

column10: b"b' Offload phpcs and static analysis checks to Scrutinizer'"

b'b" Moved phpcs and static analysis checks from travis to Scrutinizer so that overall time to run all checks is reduced. I had to make the travis\' job matrix a more verbose to ensure all jobs for code coverage with each db type are run first. Coverage report is also now submitted to scrutinizer instead of codecov. The various other checks that were done by scrutinizer by default have been disabled. In all these years I don\'t think anyone has actually checked them and made updates as per it\'s recommendations."'

b"b' What is the advantage of this mixture? Besides a bit of time saved? For me scrut always looks a bit less easy to use and buggy somewhat.  Why do we have to do coverage for all engines now? To have the edge cases also counted in? Will that in itself then increase the runtime maybe?'"

b'b"  Time saved is the main advantage. With all it\'s default checks turned off it now only shows issues for CS failures and it\'s pretty clean. e.g. url  There are some tests which are engine specific hence coverage checks need to be run for all engines to get proper coverage report. Earlier too coverage jobs were run for all engines on travis
column11: before the matrix was tweaked recently to circumvent the bug in codecov\'s report uploader. "'

column10: b"b' Interesting that the progress cannot be seen from this PR url  is not linked anywhere until completion I assume? Yeah
column11: that is definitely necessary with this tool
column12: lots of noise and often even false positives reported.'"

column10: b'b" We can try scrutinizer again. In the past it was pretty inconsistent with when and what pulls it reported on. I\'ll approve the app so we can try it out on this repo before rolling it out to other repositories."'

b"b' postgres: where clause with spaces in double quoted identifier fails'"
b'b\' This is a (multiple allowed):  * [x] bug * [ ] enhancement * [ ] feature-discussion (RFC)  * CakePHP Version: 3.7.5 * Platform and Target: postgres 9.6
column11: php 7.0
column12: linux  ### What you did We are porting some queries to cakephp that use a legacy table with column names that require double quotes.  There are some columns that have spaces such as "Total Pounds".  When adding a where() clause to a query
column13: we double-quoted the column name: where->([\\\'"Total Pounds" >= 0])  We do not have identifier quoting enabled.  ### What happened The generated SQL modified the column name in the where clause only to "Total pounds".  ### What you expected to happen I expected the identifier in the where clause to be left as-is. This did not seem to occur in other places we used the quoted identifier.  I checked for similar issues and found one involving backslashes which seems different than this case as this doesn\\\'t seem to interfere with cake or php language.  For this similar query scenario
column14: I replaced it with a query expression which did not modify the double quoted identifier.  I did find an issue mentioning spaces dropped for cakephp 2 that met with some nasty rejection so I expect something similar here.  Dropping anyway as it doesn\\\'t seem to be tracked yet for others to find.\''

column10: b'b"  If you have identifiers needing quoting why wouldn\'t you enable identifier quoting?  Your solution to use an expression is the right approach if you don\'t want to enable identifier quoting. If your interested in fixing this you would want to [look hereabouts]url Edit. Fatfingered and accidentally \'t include link."'
b'b\' So
column11: we don\\\'t enable automatic identifier quoting because that doesn\\\'t work with spaces (as expected though).  With identifier quoting
column12: the expression becomes "Total" pounds  Let me clarify the scenarios:  1. No automatic quoting + no manual quoting  Total pounds  2. No automatic quoting + manual quoting  "Total pounds"  3. Automatic quoting + no manual quoting  "Total" pounds  4. Automatic quoting + manual quoting  "Total pounds"  In all scenarios the 2nd word is lower cased. \''

column10: b'b" Looking at the code you linked
column11: I\'m guessing this is the culprit.  The expression is actually anything to the left of the last space in this scenario while this makes the operator everything to the right of the first space.  "'

column10: b"b' with the current state of the code
column11: you need to take care of this manually by using and use the API to build conditions instead of the shorthand way of using arrays'"

column10: b'b" As a convenience feature
column11: the ORM maps column types to specific classes. That is done automatically
column12: though if the user wishes
column13: they may specify a specific type for a given column.  In this case
column14: we appear to be mapping the column to a [DateTimeType]url  instance.  We\'re super-unlikely to change the output here the serialization has been the same for our ORM for a very long time
column15: and going backwards to the raw string type would essentially be what we did in pre-3.x era. If you wish to have a different serialization
column16: you can:  [Map a custom type]url  to columns in your app schema. I think you can subclass the Date(Time) ones and override the method to do what you want. [Use the database layer directly]url  Modify the query results in your after-find using [MapReduce]url  statements. Use another ORM. I know of several folks using Doctrine in their CakePHP apps. You are free to use Eloquent in your apps too. Use PDO instead of our ORM. PDO is a lightweight wrapper around database connections and queries
column17: while our ORM is exactly that an Object Relational Mapper. It\'s heavyweight
column18: and adds a lot more functionality to the query model that you cannot easily do with a simple string.  Hope this makes sense."'
